Bug.Summery: BuilderPropertyPage should have both enable and disable buttons
Bug.WithStack:
To quickly enable and disable a set of builders, we have found that users want to have separate enable and disable buttons. Why not use a check box list? (Don't let the check marks change on builders that cannot be disabled - grey them out as checked). We could take the checkbox approach, but it will probably require rewriting a lot of the BuilderPropertyPage. It's currently implemented using an SWT Table. While implemeting the multi-select behavior, I went ahead and added the two separate buttons. If we want to change the UI to a checkbox tree viewer, we can open a new bug report.
I don't recommend this approach, though, simply because I don't think it's worth the effort.
Please verify enable/disable buttons. Nls was a little screwy and the mneumonics were dupliated. Verified. I must of missed your update to the properties file...I am still not sure I like the new team stuff...

(Don't let the check marks change on builders that cannot be disabled - grey them out as checked). We could take the checkbox approach, but it will probably require rewriting a lot of the BuilderPropertyPage. It's currently implemented using an SWT Table. While implemeting the multi-select behavior, I went ahead and added the two separate buttons. If we want to change the UI to a checkbox tree viewer, we can open a new bug report.
I don't recommend this approach, though, simply because I don't think it's worth the effort.

Bug.Summery: [quick assist] [extract method] Calling extract method from a selection
Bug.WithStack:
In 3.0M2 If you select the following code (up to the very last character) and ask for "extract method" you'll get an error dialog indication "Selection ends inside a comment"
foo();//a comment The problem is that the scanner contains the newline characters (/n/r ....) in the length of the line comment.
Moving to JDT/Core to comment on the rational to contain newline characters in line comments. In fact, new line is not in comment... this is current way to check it which is not correct. Scanner current position (got with #getCurrentScannerEndPosition()) after having parsed a line comment is set after new line characters. But, comment stored position does not include them (ie. ends at first line character '\r'). So, the only issue here is that you're missing a way to get this correct line comment end...
Note that this happens also in 2.1.3 Back to JDT/UI. I will open a new bug against JDT/Core component and put this bug as dependent. Then, you'll have a track to modify CommentAnanlyser as soon as new API will be available...
Thanks Frederic. I cannot reproduce using 3.3 RC4... Do you know how this issue was fixed without the new API on IScanner (see bug 81784)?
(In reply to comment #0) > In 3.0M2 > If you select the following code (up to the very last character) and ask > for "extract method" you'll get an error dialog indication "Selection ends > inside a comment" > > foo();//a comment
'Refactor > Extract method' works with 3.8 M3. However, 'Extract to method' proposal is not offered with Ctrl+1.
Fix to go in QuickAssistProcessor.getExtractMethodProposal(...). The "if (coveringNode instanceof Block)" statement looks wrong, it might be better to just create the refactoring and let it handle all the cases.
I will investigate. (In reply to comment #6) > Fix to go in QuickAssistProcessor.getExtractMethodProposal(...). The "if > (coveringNode instanceof Block)" statement looks wrong, it might be better to > just create the refactoring and let it handle all the cases.
The 'Extract to Method' quick assist was not offered most of the times when more than one statement was selected! Small bug in getIndex(..) method used by the if statement which I have fixed. The if statement by itself is a cheap test before we create the refactoring, hence I have left it as is. I have also added a few basic tests for the quick assist, there were none previously.
Fixed in master - 1271a2793e6915e1202f090c69cab99b5943a19d

Bug.Summery: [Navigator] Only Java projects appear.
Bug.WithStack:
I copied a workspace that I created with M2 into the eclipse-SDK-I20030806-macosx- carbon.tar.gz build and started Eclipse. I had three java projects and two simple projects in the workspace. I noticed that the Navigator was displaying only the java projects (although the java Package Explorer displayed them all(!)).
To see if only the old simple projects failed to display, I tried creating a new simple project. It too was not visible in the Navigator (but was in the Package Explorer). Hm... The situation is even odder than that. I continued working for a while, and then noticed that now only one project was visible in the Navigator, and it was one of the *simple* projects.
I'm not sure what is going on at this point. It's possible that there may be some odd interaction between the concurrency work, the fact that the repository that contained some of the projects was not accessible, and the navigator changes. In any case, it appears that this drop is not usable for me. I created three Java projects and two simple projects with M2. They all show up fine in the Navigator with the 20030806 build. Tested this on Windows though. Do you still have the workspace that causes trouble with the 0806 build? Can you put it somewhere so I can download it? I do not have the workspace. I will try to recreate the problem case, if I get a chance. The workspace I was running had background sync turned on, and a couple of the projects (one java one simple) were in a repository that was not accessible. If you can't make the case happen on a Mac either, then I'd be willing to believe the problem was related to that. On the Mac, I loaded three Java projects and two simple projects from the repository using the M2 build. I ran the same workspace using the 20030806 build, disconnected the network cable (-> inaccessible repository), enabled background synchronization (set to one minute refresh interval) and the workspace content is still displayed fine in the Navigator. Can I close this PR? Since I haven't seen the problem re-appear, and could not make it happen with the few attempts I tried, you might as well close it. I'll re-open if it happens again. Reopen if needed.

Bug.Summery: Progress indicator stays red after error is cleared.
Bug.WithStack:
In the eclipse-SDK-I20030806-macosx-carbon.tar.gz build, I got an error in a CVS background job. The Progress view appeared, and I selected the error and picked Delete in the context menu. At this point, the error indicator went grey, since no other jobs were running.
However, now whenever a new job runs, the progress indicator draws in red, even though there are no new errors visible in the Progress view.
If I select "Clear All Errors", the progress indicator goes back to drawing in blue. However, I should not have had to do this, since there were no errors to clear. This was because we did npt reset the showing error flag when all errors removed. Fixed in build >20030808 Marking closed
Bug.WithOutStack:
In the eclipse-SDK-I20030806-macosx-carbon.tar.gz build, I got an error in a CVS background job. The Progress view appeared, and I selected the error and picked Delete in the context menu. At this point, the error indicator went grey, since no other jobs were running.
However, now whenever a new job runs, the progress indicator draws in red, even though there are no new errors visible in the Progress view.
If I select "Clear All Errors", the progress indicator goes back to drawing in blue. However, I should not have had to do this, since there were no errors to clear. This was because we did npt reset the showing error flag when all errors removed. Fixed in build >20030808 Marking closed

Bug.Summery: Progress error indicator does not flash if mouse is not moved.
Bug.WithStack:
If an error occurs in a background thread, the progress indicator is supposed to turn red and flash. On the Macintosh, it turns red, then flashes once or twice, but then stops until the mouse is moved. Moving the mouse enough to keep the UI live, will cause the indicator to continue to flash.
Are we failing to wake the UI thread after we draw each flash state change? Does this happen for free in syncExec, but not in asyncExec? Is it just a Mac bug? I suspect that this is the Mac that is the issue - the animate job itself does not use the UI so it should be be affected by waiting on something to release the UI Thread. The UI may need to be awake in order to make what you are doing become visible. This could be a limitation of the Mac only. Adding SN to the CC list to see what he thinks... This looks like a "wiggly mouse" bug on the Mac. When there are async's, we should never be going to sleep. It could be that the error that is happening in the background thread causes something bad to happen ...?
Please find me. This functionality has been removed I know at one point, a similar problem occured for the regular "background activity indicator" icon as well. Was that fixed? Was the underlying Mac only problem fixed? It seems like it's a bit early to mark this as invalid. Perhaps if there is no more work to be done at the UI level, it could be passed to SWT? No Mac specific work was done for this -- I just removed the code. If there is still a problem with the progress indicator then this should be reopened.

Are we failing to wake the UI thread after we draw each flash state change? Does this happen for free in syncExec, but not in asyncExec? Is it just a Mac bug? Bug.Summery: Border draws through fast views
Bug.WithStack: In the eclipse-SDK-I20030806-macosx-carbon.tar.gz build, I am seeing frequent instances where, as fastviews are updated, the border of one of the views underneath it is drawn on top of the fastview. SSQ to check Mac clipping code. This is fixed by bug#41467.
Bug.WithOutStack: In the eclipse-SDK-I20030806-macosx-carbon.tar.gz build, I am seeing frequent instances where, as fastviews are updated, the border of one of the views underneath it is drawn on top of the fastview. SSQ to check Mac clipping code. This is fixed by bug#41467.

Bug.Summery: [ViewMgmt] Fast views are too hard to recognize.
Bug.WithStack:
When fastviews are open, it is too hard to distinguish them from other views. Particularly if they have been resized to align with one of the vertical sashes in the underlying perspective. Given this, and the the fact that when you switch away from the perspective and switch back, the fastview is not hidden, it is too easy to mistake the fastview for one of the perspective's other views.
We should make fastviews easier to recognize; for example, by drawing them with a distinct border, a different background color, and/or some kind of visual indication of the connection between the view and the icon in the perspective toolbar. Another point to consider wrt the new look. fastviews look different then views in the workbench right now. For example they do not have tabs and they have a different border.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When fastviews are open, it is too hard to distinguish them from other views. Particularly if they have been resized to align with one of the vertical sashes in the underlying perspective. Given this, and the the fact that when you switch away from the perspective and switch back, the fastview is not hidden, it is too easy to mistake the fastview for one of the perspective's other views.
We should make fastviews easier to recognize; for example, by drawing them with a distinct border, a different background color, and/or some kind of visual indication of the connection between the view and the icon in the perspective toolbar. Another point to consider wrt the new look. fastviews look different then views in the workbench right now. For example they do not have tabs and they have a different border.

Bug.Summery: CVS compare works incorrectly, well it sucks
Bug.WithStack:
CVS compare in eclipse groups changes incorrectly.
Large chunks are highlighted and mismatched between panes. E.g. A change containing a method in the left pane would match to something on the right where that method isn't present, at the same time the same method in the right pane mismatches with another block on the left side.
Maybe get some inspiration form kompare and cervisia, these tools work really well. Would it be too hard to provide an example of where this happens? I would have to say that your PR really sucks based on the information you have provided :)
If you do manage to provide an example, please log the bug against the compare component. The CVS plugin uses the generic compare framework.
Bug.WithOutStack:
CVS compare in eclipse groups changes incorrectly.
Large chunks are highlighted and mismatched between panes. E.g. A change containing a method in the left pane would match to something on the right where that method isn't present, at the same time the same method in the right pane mismatches with another block on the left side.
Maybe get some inspiration form kompare and cervisia, these tools work really well. Would it be too hard to provide an example of where this happens? I would have to say that your PR really sucks based on the information you have provided :)
If you do manage to provide an example, please log the bug against the compare component. The CVS plugin uses the generic compare framework.

This error occured when I was using gnome-2.3.5, I am not sure which version of gtk, that required, but probably different from gnome-2.2. From the Gnome homepage: "GNOME 2.3.x is an unstable development series intended for testing and hacking purposes." "September 10 2.4.0 FINAL release"
I run on gnome 2.2 every day and I never saw this problem before. I closing this bug as worksforme. Please, reopen this bug if this problem happen to you on gnome 2.2.

Bug.Summery: Add Emacs plugin
Bug.WithStack:
The text editor in Eclipse is pretty limited, e.g. no split screen.
Lots of programmers know and love their Emacs.
How about a plugin?
Or, if such a plugin exists, perhaps an article on the Eclipse web-site to market it?
yvind Third party opportunity. *** Bug 47342 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I agree it's not a deadlock but most of the time I wait for minutes to get an OutOfMemoryException.
There was a bug in the UI Animation job (which spins the busy icon in the upper right), which caused it to reschedule itself in a tight loop during shutdown. Tod is aware of this bug I'm not sure when a fix will be available. This is probably at least part of the problem (I'm not sure if this would have caused out of memory errors though).
Adam's second stack trace looks like a duplicate of a real deadlock that was in that integration build: bug 41515. This one is fixed for this week's build. I have fixed the animate loop problem in HEAD. FYI, the past 2 times that I have shut down Eclipse I have had to wait several minutes for it to complete. Also, like Adam, it was taking up to 500M of memory.
I didn't get a deadlock or OutOfMemory exception though, it just took a long time and a lot of memory.
Unfortuanatly I wasn't running with java.exe so I couldn't get a stack trace. Have switched to run with a console and will provide more info if/when available. Has anyone seen this with 3.0 M3 or greater? Closing, I believe this is fixed. Please reopen if you see this again.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20030806
It does not look like a deadlock since the CPU runs at 100%

I agree it's not a deadlock but most of the time I wait for minutes to get an OutOfMemoryException.
There was a bug in the UI Animation job (which spins the busy icon in the upper right), which caused it to reschedule itself in a tight loop during shutdown. Tod is aware of this bug I'm not sure when a fix will be available. This is probably at least part of the problem (I'm not sure if this would have caused out of memory errors though).
Adam's second stack trace looks like a duplicate of a real deadlock that was in that integration build: bug 41515. This one is fixed for this week's build. I have fixed the animate loop problem in HEAD. FYI, the past 2 times that I have shut down Eclipse I have had to wait several minutes for it to complete. Also, like Adam, it was taking up to 500M of memory.
I didn't get a deadlock or OutOfMemory exception though, it just took a long time and a lot of memory.
Unfortuanatly I wasn't running with java.exe so I couldn't get a stack trace. Have switched to run with a console and will provide more info if/when available. Has anyone seen this with 3.0 M3 or greater? Closing, I believe this is fixed. Please reopen if you see this again.

Dani - do you know what you were doing when this occured? No - I found this in .log.
This was due to the subtask having the wrong type (a Job rather than JobInfo) for a parent. It was hard to replicate as it doesn't get asked for parents that often.
Fixed in build >20030811 Marking closed

Bug.Summery: "Link with Editor" in Java Outline should link on activation
Bug.WithStack:
I normally work with "Link with Editor" switched off.
When editing a long method whose head is out of view, I want to know in which method I am without leaving the editing position. I'd like to *double*click on "Link with Editor" in the Java Outline to synchronize it with the current position (the second click just disables "Link with Editor" again).
This works nicely with the Package Explorer, where a doubleclick on "Link with Editor" reveals the current file. I think this doubleclick behavior should be consistently supported by all "Link with Editor" actions. Created attachment 5682 Proposed patch. Sorry for the cumbersome problem description above. The PR's summary should read: "Link with Editor" in Java Outline should link on activation.
The goal is simply to establish the link to the actual edit position already when the button is checked (and not only when the text cursor moves). Patch rejected: it would cause an instable Java Outline page (see bug 40074).
Available in builds > 20030818

Bug.Summery: conditional breakpoint on another breakpoint
Bug.WithStack:
Hi!
Would it not be nice if one could say: "only stop at this breakpoint in <some-code-that-is-executed-often> if i have hit the breakpoint at <some-other-code> in the same call sequence" ?
The feature should just be like any other conditional breakpoints - just that you instead of a coded conditions selects one or more breakpoints that MUST have been hit before the conditional breakpoints gets "activated".
This would make my life much easier when debugging code that is very often executed, but i only want to see it when this other part of my code has been executed.
Hope you like the idea ;) Yes, I thought this would be nice too. The feature request is currently deferred, but it is good to know that somebody else wants this too.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 33936 ***

Bug.Summery: [misc] new feature for packages
Bug.WithStack:
Hi,
I will explain my proposal using an example:
If I have in my code something like lbView = new javax.swing.JLabel(); I want thru a command to transform it in like lbView = new JLabel(); and to automatically add import javax.swing.JLabel();
A special attention is needed. An example is java.util.Date and java.sql.Date.
Thanks and best regards, piri Hi,
I got no answer yet, is it so stupid?
thanks, piri Is available for some time now (at least since 2.0): - Organize Imports (default key binding: Ctrl+Shift+O) - Add Import (default key binding: Ctrl+Shift+M)
Bug.WithOutStack:
Hi,
I will explain my proposal using an example:
If I have in my code something like lbView = new javax.swing.JLabel(); I want thru a command to transform it in like lbView = new JLabel(); and to automatically add import javax.swing.JLabel();
A special attention is needed. An example is java.util.Date and java.sql.Date.
Thanks and best regards, piri Hi,
I got no answer yet, is it so stupid?
thanks, piri Is available for some time now (at least since 2.0): - Organize Imports (default key binding: Ctrl+Shift+O) - Add Import (default key binding: Ctrl+Shift+M)

Bug.Summery: [misc] Automatically remove unused imports on save

Lines.Line: - correct operation together with team providers
- the modified code might introduce errors or corrupt the code

Bug.WithStack:
I keep removing unused imports - it would be useful to have an option to have this done automatically on save.
Channing dup of bug 6749 Not a duplicate but rather a subset of the things listed in bug 6749.
Could anyone attach some hints of where one would hook a plugin to satisify this bug? Just pointing us in the right direction might lead to some contributions here. I really want to see auto organizing of imports on save. Hooking stuff into the save operation affects many areas and introduces several problems that need to be handled/solved, e.g.: - correct operation together with team providers - local file history - undo/redo history - the modified code might introduce errors or corrupt the code - modifying the code might fail (exception) ...
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 6749 ***

Bug.Summery: State of RetargetAction with style="toggle" is wrong
Bug.WithStack:
I20030806
In XML I defined an action with style="toggle" and retarget="true". This results in a RetargetAction which has NO style bit set (which is OK if we want to allow to change the shape later) but in RetargetAction.setActionHandler it asks for its style when retargeting.
I attached a patch where the style retrieved from the concrete handler.
Note: There are other problems when defining a style and retarget="true", e.g. how would he menu of a retargeted pulldown button be requested. Created attachment 5690 Patch for RetargetAction I took a different approach which is to set the style on the RetargetAction. If the XML says retarget="true" and style="toggle", then it's always a toggle, independent of what the handler says. Also, getting the style from the handler would not support style="radio" since this can only be set when first creating the action.
Simon, could you please review my changes? I changed PartEventAction, RetargetAction, LabelRetargetAction and WWinPluginAction.
Yes this is even the better approach. Will this also fix the problem with the style="pulldown": I have also a retargeted pulldown action but there the retargeted action only gets informed about button being pressed. The drop down menu is not opened. To get the menu I had to register a delegate in the XML (class="...") which handles the menu. I think the correct behavior would be to delegate the opening of the drop down menu to the retargeted action as well.
If it's retargetable, you should not have to specify class=. I doubt my fix addresses this.
Simon, can you please look at this one? Since Simon should review the change for this bug I assume it is in tomorrows I-build, correct? If not, I can change the toggle to a push button for the I-build since the state of the toggle is incorrect. Should I file another PR for the pulldown style problem?
The code was released to HEAD, so it will be in the I-build. I did some testing using the Readme example, but I recommend you testing against HEAD too before the I-build. Nick, I looked at the code and it seems fine.
As for the pulldown attribute, let me know with this fix if you still have the same problem. I'm busy with the RCP work right now so it may be post M3 before I get a chance to look into this. I verified this bug using HEAD. The pulldown style problem is not fixed by this fix. I filed bug 41401 for it so that this report can be closed.
Ok, closing.

I attached a patch where the style retrieved from the concrete handler.

Bug.Summery: Preferences->Workbench->Appearance crashes JVM [Motif]

Lines.Line: Now Eclipse terminates with a message box "JVM terminated. Exit code=6..."

Bug.WithStack:
Steps to Reproduce 1.) Open "Window->Preferences" 2.) Expand Workbench 3.) Click on Appearance Now Eclipse terminates with a message box "JVM terminated. Exit code=6..."
Build Date: Nightly Build, Build id: 200308080010 (Milestone M2 doesn't crash the JVM)
Platform: Debian, Linux 2.4.21-3-686 #1 Sun Jul 20 16:11:09 EST 2003 i686 GNU/Linux
Tested Java-Versions (both crashed): Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_02-b06) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_02-b06, mixed mode) Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2-beta-b19) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-beta-b19, mixed mode) Created attachment 5691 JVM error report file There was a two day period where we released bogus code on Motif and you are one of the lucky ones that hit it. It's been fixed for a while but it you see it again or in another nightly, either reopen this PR or enter a new one. Thanks.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Steps to Reproduce 1.) Open "Window->Preferences" 2.) Expand Workbench 3.) Click on Appearance Now Eclipse terminates with a message box "JVM terminated. Exit code=6..."
Build Date: Nightly Build, Build id: 200308080010 (Milestone M2 doesn't crash the JVM)
Platform: Debian, Linux 2.4.21-3-686 #1 Sun Jul 20 16:11:09 EST 2003 i686 GNU/Linux
Tested Java-Versions (both crashed): Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_02-b06) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_02-b06, mixed mode) Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2-beta-b19) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-beta-b19, mixed mode) Created attachment 5691 JVM error report file There was a two day period where we released bogus code on Motif and you are one of the lucky ones that hit it. It's been fixed for a while but it you see it again or in another nightly, either reopen this PR or enter a new one. Thanks.

Bug.Summery: [Tasks] Filters are not applied to Problems view after eclipse start
Bug.WithStack:
The Problems view filters are not applied when Eclipse first starts up and the Problems view is present in the perspective. Simply opening the filters and clicking OK is enough for the filters to be applied.
Channing *** Bug 42455 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is a regression from 2.1 *** Bug 40567 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 40701 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Same problem exists on Tasks view. update: My workaround of opening the filters and clicking OK is no longer working in build 200309300800 Need to address for M5. Channing,
Can you try your workaround in I20031008 (or later). I suspect it will work again. Please annotate with your findings. will do the workaround does work in I20031008 again. *** Bug 45013 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 45218 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 45906 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I think this was fixed as part of the work on bug 44443. It does not seem to be happening as of build 200312091137. Fixed with bug 44443.
Fix available I200312109+. Verified in I200312160800 in Problems View and Tasks View.

Bug.Summery: Use 'is' prefix for getters that return Boolean. [code manipulation]
Bug.WithStack:
Window > Preferences > Java > Code Generation > Use 'is' prefix for getters that return boolean works only for boolean, not for Boolean. Martin, what is the standard here. Hm, I never thought abaout that. I browsed the web for specification and the only case that is mentionied for 'is ' is boolean.
If you can point me to some other spec; I'll gladly add Boolean too. Please reopen in this case.
As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Window > Preferences > Java > Code Generation > Use 'is' prefix for getters that return boolean works only for boolean, not for Boolean. Martin, what is the standard here. Hm, I never thought abaout that. I browsed the web for specification and the only case that is mentionied for 'is ' is boolean.
If you can point me to some other spec; I'll gladly add Boolean too. Please reopen in this case.
As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Getting fragments for a bundle is not implemented
Bug.WithStack: Gettting fragments was is implemented on BundleContext... and is not available on Bundle. Fixed the API and implementation.
Bug.WithOutStack: Gettting fragments was is implemented on BundleContext... and is not available on Bundle. Fixed the API and implementation.

It seems as if it's trailing one character behind...

Bug.Summery: Import|filesystem Form Directory input acts strange
Bug.WithStack:
Debian Packages, gtk Version of eclipse 2.1.1
File|Import|File System -> In the 'Form Directory' files is nothing. Browse the filesystem and select your user Dir: From Directory is now '/home/user/' (also note, that on motif it is '/home/user'). Add a char -> the char is inserted at the end of the string and the caret jumps to the front. When you go on typing, you will end up with a mirrored string of your typing, as the caret always junps to the start: 'espilc/home/jan/e' for /home/jan/eclipse. Motif version behaves as it should.
apt-cache policy libgtk2.0-0 libgtk2.0-0: Installed: 2.2.2-1woody2 Candidate: 2.2.2-1woody2
Thanks! Jan FH says he and SSQ know what this is. Assigning to him. Can you verify if this problem happens with the latest Eclipse ? Eclipse 3.0 M2 for example ?
No I don't have a download of that. I will download M2 on sunday (I only have ISDN net access, which is free on sunday) and have a go.
Is that a gtk issue? It should be fairly easy to reproduce on a debian sid system... If I'm not wrong I've already fixed this problem (not the same scenario but the source of the problem is problaby the same) for Eclipse 3.0.
Any patch, which I can try? I build eclipse from source, so applying a patch isn't a problem. Also, if this bugfix isn't backported to 2.1.2, I will anyway try to backport that for the debian packages, which I maintain. Dwnloaded sourceIncluded build, build for gtk (wow, what a change from 2.1!) File|Import|File System|Browse -> choose any dir -> Now there will be this dir in the inputfield. Append any letter or delete the leading '/' and the carret jumps to the beginning of the line. => no change... Any updates? This bug was related a bogus Selection event that was being sent by the Combo box widget. We have rewritten this part of this code and released it today. I can no longer reproduce this problem. You can verify the fix in next week integration build or any other nightly build from now on.
Fixed > 20030828 (HEAD)

Bug.Summery: [Watch/Edit] Files loose 'edit' state on cvs server after first compare with HEAD

Lines.Line: 1. Modify (edit notification sent to the server) and save a file.
2. Select the modified file (right click) and "Compare With", "Latest from HEAD".
3. Double click the file in CVS Compare window.
1) Come up with another way to get the advanced funtionality
2) Track the edited files on the server and re-edit them when the edit state is lost
3) Add support to the CVS server for the advanced Eclipse functionality
4) Remove the advanced funtionality from Eclipse
- Double click on a file in Team Synchronizing Perspective
- Compare with specific revision or version
There is no plan to address this item.
I'm very disappointed to learn that you have no plans to resolve such a long-standing critical fault in the Eclipse CVS plugin.

Bug.WithStack:
At the moment you open the Compare editor after a "Compare With", "Latest from HEAD", the opened file looses its 'edit' state on the CVS server.
How to reproduce: 1. Modify (edit notification sent to the server) and save a file. 2. Select the modified file (right click) and "Compare With", "Latest from HEAD". 3. Double click the file in CVS Compare window.
At the moment you perform item 3, the server looses the 'edit' state. This happens, because it sends 0 bytes for the file and uses the -C argument for the update. Together they cause the server to think the locally modified file was overwritten and it removes the 'edit' state. Eclipse however did not overwrite the local file, it only uses it for the comparison somehow. This happens only on the first compare, any succeeding compare from within Eclipse does not use this update command. It looks like the file is cached somewhere.
Find below the request (>) and response (<) for the one time update that occurs. >Root /data/cvs/test >Global_option -r >Argument -r >Argument 1.1 >Argument -C >Argument -d >Argument -P >Directory . >/data/cvs/test/tzt >Entry /JustAClass.java/1.1//-ko/ >Modified JustAClass.java >u=rw,g=rw,o=r >0 >Argument JustAClass.java >Directory . >/data/cvs/test/tzt >update <New-entry ./ </data/cvs/test/tzt/JustAClass.java </JustAClass.java/1.1//-ko/T1.1 <M U JustAClass.java <Update-existing ./ </data/cvs/test/tzt/JustAClass.java </JustAClass.java/1.1//-ko/T1.1 <u=r,g=r,o=r <29 <public class JustAClass { < <} <ok
This has been tested and found with the following combinations: Eclipse (win32) cvs (server), RedHat8 2.1 1.11.5 2.1.1 1.11.5 2.1.1 1.11.6
The project uses Watch/Edit and "Send a cvs edit notification to the server". Post 3.0 Just a small observation:
I can reproduce this problem as described using CVS 1.12.9 via pserver on debian sarge.
But I can not reproduce it using CVSNT 2.0.9 on Win2K. *** Bug 110099 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 130513 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I am suprised that such a serious fault has been open for such a long time. Can I suggest that the severity of this bug is increased to Critical? For users that use CVS Watch/Edit functionality for enforcing informal exclusive locking (as CVS offers no other alternatives) this fault is a major cause of data loss! You are free to set the severity if you like. The component committers don't set severity.
As for your other point, there are a couple of reasons why this bug has not been addressed. The main reason is that the solution to the problem is not obvious. The Eclipse CVS client does a bunch of things that the basic command line client does not (e.g. Synchronization, Comparisons). The implementation of these features uses the "cvs update" command on a fake sandbox which seems to fake out the server into thinking that the user is no longer editing the file. Possible solutions could be:
1) Come up with another way to get the advanced funtionality 2) Track the edited files on the server and re-edit them when the edit state is lost 3) Add support to the CVS server for the advanced Eclipse functionality 4) Remove the advanced funtionality from Eclipse
I think that point 2 is impossible and point 3 will never happen. We couldn't do point 4 since the majority of our customers use this funtionality. That leaves point 1 and unfortunately, I don't know how we would accomplish this. That's not to say it's impossible but the solution isn't obvious. Michael, thanks for the reply - I did attempt to set the severity but BugZilla doesn't appear to allow this on a bug I don't own and didn't raise. Obviously as an end user I was hoping such a severity would translate into an increased priority!
You seem to be saying that the Watch/Edit functionality has never and will never work properly, so I'm suprised it has ever been included in Eclipse. I've never seen any warnings or disclaimers about this functionality?
From your brief description it does sound like the Eclipse CVS client code's design has some fundamental flaws, but surely a work around can be found? For example, whenever it invokes an "update -C" it could then re-invoke the Edit functionality afterwards? Perhaps it isn't that simple, and it would probably have a performance cost, but the client knows which files are being compared? Alternatively I'm sure there are other ways of getting a specific/latest version of a file in CVS other than "update -C" (although I don't pretend to be a CVS expert).
I didn't realize that there were restrictions on who could set the severity. I've set the severity as you requested.
As for the Watch/Edit support, I didn't say it would never work, I said that you can't use Synchronize or Compare if you don't want the edit state lost. You can still use the basic update and commit workflows. As for why Watch/Edit is included, the answer is simple: Eclipse is open source and most of the watch/edit support was contributed by community members. Your point about documenting the shortcomings is well taken. We should add an entry to the readme file.
As for your proposal, I would be happy if someone could tell me a reliable and efficient way to get contents without using update. It would be possible to get synchronizations and comparisons using "cvs diff" but this will only work for some files. If we need to use diff for some files and update for others, there wil be a noticable performance impact. Thanks for updating the severity - I hope this will to more time being spent looking at it.
I understand your comments about why the Watch/Edit code was originally included, however isolating it as "highly experimental" might have been a good idea at the time. Not being able to take CVS updates in a controlled manner (synchronise) or double check what has been edited before committing a change(compare) are (IMHO) essential uses cases without which we (as a team) would not be able to use CVS.
Restricting compare to text files (supported by cvs diff) sounds a perfectly reasonable solution if it means Watch/Edit will function correctly. Here is an update to help focus investigation of this issue - on Eclipse 3.1.2 on Windows XP, JDK 1.4.2 and CVS 1.11.18 (on Linux) the "synchronise" functionality itself doesn't cause this fault to be triggered, only the various "compare" options:
- Compare with latest from Head - Double click on a file in Team Synchronizing Perspective - Compare with specific revision or version There is no plan to address this item. I'm very disappointed to learn that you have no plans to resolve such a long-standing critical fault in the Eclipse CVS plugin.
This will force my company, and any others that need some sort of locking in CVS, to move away from Eclipse to alternatives such as NetBeans.
That is a shame. What it really boils down to is priorities. We have limited resources and a lot of work items to be addressed in 3.3. Our main focus is to support the developement of Eclipse.org projects but we do want to support other workflows if the amount of effort is reasonable. My feeling is that addressing this bug would be a considerable amount of work and would require us to drop higher priority items.
Traditionaly, it has been the community that has provided patches for the Watch/Edit support. Are you willing to help out with this in some form? If so, we would be willing to reconsider. Perhaps we would be able to come up with a reasonable solution that is not a major rework of how comparisons are done. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: NPE and resource exception when comparing an out of sync file

Lines.Line: 2) Edit a file under CVS control externally (I did this with our buildnotes)
4) Go to the synch view and refresh (I think this is where the CVS Exception
5) The file will show up as a conflict. Double click on it
6) Internal error is shown (the NPE below)

Bug.WithStack:
20030806
When I do a compare with an out of synch file I get two exceptions (I think the are in this order). I have added Mike to the list as I think this might have something to do with the problems he saw earlier in the week.
STEPS 1) Open Live Synch View 2) Edit a file under CVS control externally (I did this with our buildnotes) 3) Save it 4) Go to the synch view and refresh (I think this is where the CVS Exception came from) 5) The file will show up as a conflict. Double click on it 6) Internal error is shown (the NPE below)

(StructuredViewer.java:602) at org.eclipse.jface.viewers.StructuredViewer$6.handleOpen (StructuredViewer.java:690) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy.fireOpenEvent (OpenStrategy.java:211) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy.access$2(OpenStrategy.java:204) at org.eclipse.jface.util.OpenStrategy$1.handleEvent (OpenStrategy.java:340) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:88) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:596) I wasn't able to get the NPE but I did notice a couple of other strangeness with resources that are out-of-sync (OOS) with the file system.
1. opening the compare editor with an OOS resource shows the local as empty. This is because the ResourceNode eats the CoreException and return null.
2. the background sync chokes on OOS resources because the CVS plugin doesn't handle them well. We should investigate how to refresh files in these cases and ensuring that the CVS meta files are also loaded. The problem is that a refresh will cause a delta and builds... Can we *please* just build in "auto-sync with the filesystem"? The old behavior was never what people wanted anyway.
If the auot-refresh plugin was available, would there still exist cases where a file is out-of-sync? I assume that on Linux this would be true because the verification algorithm is a simple poll. Well, yes... But clearly at any point where we currently detect the case and put up a dialog, we could just detect the case and do the refresh. This plus the background (polled) update would likely work well enough for all situations.
The NPE is fixed but the refresh problem is still valid. Marking as dupe of our refresh with file system bug.

Bug.Summery: Show Hierarchy and Show Outline should show Javadocs
Bug.WithStack:
The quick views (Show Hierarchy and Show Outline, Ctrl+T and Ctrl+O) should provide context info for the current selection (type / member), like every ContentAssist does.
To avoid cluttering the screen, the additional info could only be shown when a tree item is active (and not when the search text line has focus). It's not a content assist. If you want to see the Javadoc either use the Javadoc view or jump to the corresponding method.
Get rid of deprecated state.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The quick views (Show Hierarchy and Show Outline, Ctrl+T and Ctrl+O) should provide context info for the current selection (type / member), like every ContentAssist does.
To avoid cluttering the screen, the additional info could only be shown when a tree item is active (and not when the search text line has focus). It's not a content assist. If you want to see the Javadoc either use the Javadoc view or jump to the corresponding method.
Get rid of deprecated state.

Bug.Summery: [Help] help could be installed in a more flexible way
Bug.WithStack:
Currently if you want to use the help for some plug-in you have to have that plug-in installed in your Eclipse IDE. Since our current development setup is different from the one of an Eclipse developer that is not always the best option.
In our current setup we have plain Eclipse as our development IDE. In the product we are developing one of the pre-requisites is GEF. If I want to see GEF docs and help I have to install those plug-ins in my IDE even though I do not use GEF in my IDE. It is only used in the product we're developing.
There should be a better way to include help/docs without having to install the given plug-ins in your IDE. There could be an option to point to help files or plug-ins while running Eclipse and dinamically populate the help system. To view help of a plug-in that is in your workspace you do not have to install this plug-in in your IDE, you can launch it using PDE.
I do not believe that help system contained in Eclipse Platform should be able to launch help for code in the workspace, whether it is packaged as Eclipse help or other help.
I think there should be a way to view help in Eclipse format for a plug-in in the workspace only if PDE has been installed. And currently it is already possible. You can use PDE to launch runtime workbench using most plug-ins from development workbench plus the plug-in from workspace that contains help for component you are using. This lets you view help for a component without destabilizing your IDE configuration.
I agree that there an easier way not involving more than couple of mouse clicks, would be helpful, but doubt that it should be made part of Eclipse Platform or Rich Client Platform (in 3.0). It is definitely an IDE task.
Another way for an easier access to GEF documentation is to have the documentation installed on an infocenter, and be accessible using a browser. Eclipse help system supports this scenario, but some effort and resources to set up an infocenter is required on part of library provider. Marking as P4 - unlikely to be looked at for 3.1. Having remote help where you can browse help installed on a remote infocenter would allow you to browse help for plugins not installed as part of the base workbench. Marking as duplicate.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 122967 ***

Bug.Summery: Cannot get the cancel button of a WizardDialog
Bug.WithStack: In org.eclipse.jface.wizard.WizardDialog, the private createCancelButton() creates the Cancel button nicely but forgets to register this button with the map of buttons thus preventing subclasses from getting at the Cancel button. We need to get at this button to change its label. Question - why do you want to change the label? Cancel is a pretty universal concept and this string is externalized. We're designing a type of Web Services Browser around the wizard framework and would like to change the "Cancel" label to "Close". Eclipse documents that we should be able to get at this Button using getCancelButton() (which has been deprecated) or getButton(IDialogConstants.CANCEL_ID) so it should work, shouldn't it? The method createButtonsForButtonBar() was already provided so that the button creation can be overridden. I think you will want to override this anyways to avoid the other buttons you don't want.
Bug.WithOutStack: In org.eclipse.jface.wizard.WizardDialog, the private createCancelButton() creates the Cancel button nicely but forgets to register this button with the map of buttons thus preventing subclasses from getting at the Cancel button. We need to get at this button to change its label. Question - why do you want to change the label? Cancel is a pretty universal concept and this string is externalized. We're designing a type of Web Services Browser around the wizard framework and would like to change the "Cancel" label to "Close". Eclipse documents that we should be able to get at this Button using getCancelButton() (which has been deprecated) or getButton(IDialogConstants.CANCEL_ID) so it should work, shouldn't it? The method createButtonsForButtonBar() was already provided so that the button creation can be overridden. I think you will want to override this anyways to avoid the other buttons you don't want.

Bug.Summery: developing with links should be more flexible

Lines.Line: 1) Still be able to define the Target Platform (an Eclipse compatible
2) Be able to define the "link files" in the same preference page. That
preference would be stored per workspace eliminating the need of various
copies of the Target Platform application (which can be huge).
Whatever happened with this? Comment says target 3.0M6 but it's not marked fixed.
well, in 3.0M6, OSGi came and the rest is history :-)
Wassim, isn't this pretty much taken care of with target definitions (you know, those things people never use).
yes, this one is covered by a "Target Definition" where you can specify multiple locations.

Bug.WithStack:
We current develop our product using .link files and the "Target Platform" preference. In our case that makes life easier but it could be more flexible.
In our scenario we base our product in 2 other products (P1 and P2). P1 contains the base Eclipse and is the one we define in "Target Platform". Under P1 we have a link file pointing to P2. That gives us the flexibility of easially moving between P2 versions (both up and down) as necessary.
Sometimes we need to have 2 workspaces when working on different problems. In those cases it might happen that each workspace requires a different version of P2. That is where we do not have enough flexibility. Since the version of P2 is defined by the link file under P1 we have to have 2 copies of P1 in order to work with 2 versions of P2 (on different workspaces).
So, my feature request is as follows: eliminate the need of having a link file under the "Target Platform" and replace that (of course, only in development time) with:
1) Still be able to define the Target Platform (an Eclipse compatible application) 2) Be able to define the "link files" in the same preference page. That preference would be stored per workspace eliminating the need of various copies of the Target Platform application (which can be huge). target: M6 Whatever happened with this? Comment says target 3.0M6 but it's not marked fixed. well, in 3.0M6, OSGi came and the rest is history :-) investigating issue Wassim, isn't this pretty much taken care of with target definitions (you know, those things people never use). yes, this one is covered by a "Target Definition" where you can specify multiple locations.
It is under File > New > Other... > Plug-in Development > Target Definition in Eclipse >= 3.2

Bug.Summery: [Jobs] Repository view jumps to selected node on expansion
Bug.WithStack:
The repository view if you have clicked on a folder say org.junit folder in the eclipse CVS repository, and then you scroll up to say org.apache.ant and click on the + to expand that node the scroll view will jump all the way down to org.junit when the expansion is complete. It is very annoying and can be difficult for a user to understand why it is happening! Tod, this is the auto-scroll behaviour we have talked about before. When the repo view fetches the children in the background once the cihldren are added to the tree they get auto-scrolled. This is confusing because the user could have scrolled, expanded somewhere else.
I remember you mentioned some solution for this, but I forget the details.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 42158 ***

Bug.Summery: org.eclipse.swt.layout.FormData needs toString()
Bug.WithStack:
org.eclipse.swt.layout.FormData should have a meaningful toString() method for debugging purposes (FormAttachment does, so it would be logical to have one for FormData as well). What would you like it to print? No other layout data object has a toString (). So I'm tempted not to do anything. Got a good case ...? Well for starters it seems logical to print out all of the top/bottom, left/right attachments for FormData. Since FormData only contains 6 publically accessible fields it is probably worthwhile to just print all of them.
It would also be helpful to add similar methods to the other LayoutData classes as well, although I haven't had a need because we mainly use FormLayouts. Vikki, didn't you just fix this? In 3.1, toString added for all SWT layouts and their layout data.
Bug.WithOutStack:
org.eclipse.swt.layout.FormData should have a meaningful toString() method for debugging purposes (FormAttachment does, so it would be logical to have one for FormData as well). What would you like it to print? No other layout data object has a toString (). So I'm tempted not to do anything. Got a good case ...? Well for starters it seems logical to print out all of the top/bottom, left/right attachments for FormData. Since FormData only contains 6 publically accessible fields it is probably worthwhile to just print all of them.
It would also be helpful to add similar methods to the other LayoutData classes as well, although I haven't had a need because we mainly use FormLayouts. Vikki, didn't you just fix this? In 3.1, toString added for all SWT layouts and their layout data.

eclipse-I20030806 Create Patch is VCM. *** Bug 42337 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 43006 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 47342 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 50379 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 54516 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Created attachment 9862 Heres a patch against 200404201300 *** Bug 59841 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Created attachment 10223 NEw patch using CVS Team
Re-did the patch using CVS Team instead of command line Thanks for the patch. But this only solves part of the problem since currently apply patch doesn't allow multi-select. We won't be able to fix this for 3.0. *** Bug 70959 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 85760 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 96249 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 96715 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 96790 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Would Bug 103871 work as a solution to this problem? It would - the only case where it would fail would be to in creating a patch that spans projects. But I guess in that case, one could always run "Create Patch" foir each project.
See my comments in bub 103871 comment 3. I think the multi-selection can be used to prepopulate the wizard page that is requested there. Created attachment 27440 Create Patch zip Here's a patch for the workspace patcher. Main changes made to the current patching mechanism are as follows:
Create Patch - Allows multiple selections of elements - Preview page for changes contained in patch (also allows for selection of patch contents) - Patches can now be rooted at the workspace level, the project level or the selection level
Apply Patch - Wizard guides users to appropriate pages based on patch type - Allows users to retarget workspace patches for projects that don't exist in current workspace
To activate workspace patch, you have to pass in the following VM arg on startup:
-DworkspacePatch=true

I think they are localized to a few classes but, unfortunately, my development workstation just died so I can't give you the exact class names. Bug.Summery: AddJarAction has no need for a validator
Bug.WithStack:
The AddJarAction opens a tree selection dialog with a archive filter. A validator is not required as the filter will only show valid selections. Fixed in AddJarAction Please verify Luc. And changes to the ActionMessages. Verified. Validator required else you can add folders in the Java Classpath tab and leads to:
Thread [main] (Suspended (exception ClassCastException)) AntClasspathBlock.addJars(TableViewer) line: 334 AntClasspathBlock.access$1(AntClasspathBlock, TableViewer) line: 315
in the AntClasspath tab and page Fixed in AddJarAction and AntClasspathBlock. Please verify Luc. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The AddJarAction opens a tree selection dialog with a archive filter. A validator is not required as the filter will only show valid selections. Fixed in AddJarAction Please verify Luc. And changes to the ActionMessages. Verified. Validator required else you can add folders in the Java Classpath tab and leads to:

in the AntClasspath tab and page Fixed in AddJarAction and AntClasspathBlock. Please verify Luc. Verified.

Bug.Summery: [rulers] Do not enable QuickDiff by default
Bug.WithStack:
Please disable QuickDiff by default. It's a neat feature, but I don't think enough people use it (because I haven't heard many people request it) to warrant turning it on by default. How would you get to know it and try it if you never see it? What bothers you with the feature i.e. why do you want to have it disabled? Under windows it is almost not visible unless you hover over a change. I am also bothered by the QuickDiff feature because as of 3.0M6 there seems to be no way to disable it permanently. I disabled "Always show QuickDiff coloring" in "Work in progress" preferences, and nevertheless the extra margin and the ugly grey line on the left-hand side are present (I am talking about Linux/GTK here; I haven't checked it out under Windows). Hitting CTRL-SHIFT-Q makes them disappear, but when I reopen a file in the editor, they are back there!
QuickDiff might be a useful feature, but it should be available per user's request. Having switched from 2.1 to 3.0, the first thing I noticed is that the editor GUI got "somehow" uglier - and it took me some observation (plus some reading) to figure out the cause. Note that there are two settings, for the text editor and java editor, where you can turn on / off the quick diff setting. I back out from my previous comment - QuickDiff *can* be disabled as Workbench/Editors/Text Editor/QuickDiff/Always show QuickDiff coloring. The quick diff feature is not memory friendly when it comes to large documents because it creates multiple instances of the same string (string representation of the document). Check out the implementation of org.eclipse.jface.text.GapTextStore. These strings could be very large in size, so you can easlier run out of memory.
An alternate solution to disable it by default is to ask the user the first time an Eclipse editor comes up. The prompt would have a "remember this decision" checkbox that would update the preference if checked. This way, the user can decide whether to enable this or not. Cause it's not obvious to the user what "quick diff" does and where to disable/enable it. There are no plans to change this.

Bug.Summery: Javadoc: add a note about the order of getSelectedIndices() in List
Bug.WithStack:
The javadoc for List's getSelectedIndices() doesn't say anything about the ordering of the array returned. Could you add a note saying either it's sorted in (for example) ascending order, or in no particular order? Selection order, not just indices, is undefined in every widget in SWT due to the platform. Not sure where to document this.
Any ideas Vikki or do we just change the JavaDoc for every getSelection* that returns an array? I would change the javadoc for every selection that returns an array. If you update the javadoc for Windows, we can bash the comments for the other platforms. Fixed > 20050621

Bug.Summery: CCombo shouldn't fire defaultSelection on mouse list selection
Bug.WithStack:
If you drop down the combo list using the mouse and then select an entry using the mouse, the CCombo fires a defaultSelection. It shouldn't do this. It should fire a selection instead.
Default selection means something was selected and you should go and do something. The typical reaction is to process the selection and dismiss the dialog.
A combo shouldn't fire default selection from just selecting an entry in the dropdown. A typical user of a combobox would be vert surprised to have the dialog be dismissed just because the entry was selected. Standard Combos won't do this.
Because of this you can't tell the difference between just selecting an entry using the mouse and hitting enter from the text field of the CCombo. Hitting enter from the text field should be treated as default selection. Vikki, if this is true, please fix, pronto. Thanks. Fixed for I20030812 Pressing the ENTER key is still inconsistent with Combo. Combo will always allow the Shell's default button to receive the ENTER key. CCombo will never allow this to happen. This is true whether the drop-down list is being displayed or not, and for both readonly and editable widgets.
Bug.WithOutStack:
If you drop down the combo list using the mouse and then select an entry using the mouse, the CCombo fires a defaultSelection. It shouldn't do this. It should fire a selection instead.
Default selection means something was selected and you should go and do something. The typical reaction is to process the selection and dismiss the dialog.
A combo shouldn't fire default selection from just selecting an entry in the dropdown. A typical user of a combobox would be vert surprised to have the dialog be dismissed just because the entry was selected. Standard Combos won't do this.
Because of this you can't tell the difference between just selecting an entry using the mouse and hitting enter from the text field of the CCombo. Hitting enter from the text field should be treated as default selection. Vikki, if this is true, please fix, pronto. Thanks. Fixed for I20030812 Pressing the ENTER key is still inconsistent with Combo. Combo will always allow the Shell's default button to receive the ENTER key. CCombo will never allow this to happen. This is true whether the drop-down list is being displayed or not, and for both readonly and editable widgets.

Bug.Summery: Javadoc attachment to JDK-jars override [build path]

Lines.Line: or equivalent from http://java.sun.com. Use the Version that installs as JRE
Extension library. Also do download the Java3D API documentation and put it
2) Fire up Eclipse IDE and open "Window>Preferences>Java>Installed JREs>Edit JRE"

libraries in the list of System libraries ({JRE|JDK}_HOME/lib/ext/j3daudio.jar,
3) Set a Javadoc URL (e.g. "file:/C:/j2sdk1.4.2/docs/api/") in the edit JRE
Window and close it by pressing OK
4)Choose any open Project and unfold "JRE System libraries" until the three
added libraries become visible. Choose any of the three and open the library's
5) Enter path to the Java3D API documentation which is downloadable (separately
form the Java 3D installation archive) from java.sun.com in the field javadoc
location and confirm setting by closing window with OK.
6) The API documentation for the Java3D classes is now accessible by pressing F1

- expand the JRE System Library in the Package Explorer and select rt.jar,
core.jar, or whatever the main jar in your installation is
- set the Javadoc Location to "Javadoc in archive" and enter pathes for doc zip
- click OK, open type Vector and press Shift+F2
=> the javadoc is (correctly) taken from the jar for this session

Bug.WithStack:
Although it is possible to assign separate Javadoc-attachments to jars in the JRE, these assignements are overridden by the global Javadoc-attachment defined in the Preferences window of the JRE when restarting the IDE.
This behavior is especially akward with JDK extensions because it effectively hinders integration the extensions javadoc documentation. I am experiencing this problem with the Java 3D API that is installed as runtime extension in $JAVA_HOME/lib/ext (J2SDK 1.4.2/java3d-1_3_1-windows-i586-directx-sdk.exe).
The global definition of a Javadoc attachment for a JRE in the Preferences window sholud IMHO be used as a default value if there are no specific attachments defined. JRE Installation issue. Move to JDT/Debug. To clarify the problem, could please provide steps to reproduce the problem. Steps to reproduce Problem:
1) Install Java3D (java3d-1_3_1-windows-i586-directx-sdk.exe if using Windows) or equivalent from http://java.sun.com. Use the Version that installs as JRE Extension library. Also do download the Java3D API documentation and put it somewhere on your local disk.
2) Fire up Eclipse IDE and open "Window>Preferences>Java>Installed JREs>Edit JRE"
3)choose installed JRE (I use jdk1.4.2). You should see three additional libraries in the list of System libraries ({JRE|JDK}_HOME/lib/ext/j3daudio.jar, {JRE|JDK}_HOME/lib/ext/j3dcore.jar, {JRE|JDK}_HOME/lib/ext/j3dutils.jar).
3) Set a Javadoc URL (e.g. "file:/C:/j2sdk1.4.2/docs/api/") in the edit JRE Window and close it by pressing OK
4)Choose any open Project and unfold "JRE System libraries" until the three added libraries become visible. Choose any of the three and open the library's properties using the context menu.
5) Enter path to the Java3D API documentation which is downloadable (separately form the Java 3D installation archive) from java.sun.com in the field javadoc location and confirm setting by closing window with OK.
6) The API documentation for the Java3D classes is now accessible by pressing F1 in the Java editor.
7) Close Eclipse and start it again.
8) The Javadoc location entered in step 5 has been replaced by the javadoc location configured in step 3 - the Java3D API documentation is no longer accessible by pressing F1 in the Java Editor.
Martin, where is the library-specific javadoc location stored? The JRE only has one setting (i.e. for the JRE, not per library). It looks like we re-set this on startup when restoring the saved JRE settings. This fires a property change event on the JRE which you must be listening to, which in turn re-sets the javadoc location for all the libraries. Yes, that's correct, it's the JavaDocVMInstallListener which gets this single location and sets it to all library locations.
The store that keeps the javadoc location paths is in jdt.ui and the API to access it is JavaUI.set/getLibraryJavadocLocation.
You could extend the JRE LibrrayLocation to include a Javadoc location as well, so we could have it on a per JAR basis.
The reason for this complicated listener setup was that the java.launching plugin does not know of jdt.ui. *** Bug 35336 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** A point of concern.
You have marked an earlier bug, 35336, as a duplicate of this bug. My concern is that this bug appears to be concerned with functioinality which doesn't presently exist but perhaps should. The original bug was concerned with the mechanism used to implements existing functionality from a specified part of the user interface. i.e. the facility to do what is required already exists an can be proved to function properly if accessed from a different part of the user interface.
I make no claim to know if the internal workings of eclipse but would merely ask that you take care to ensure you're not about to loose a bug by hiding it behind a different, if closely related, one.
Regards,
Cliff Evans My understanding of the problem is that a user can assign a javadoc location to each jar in a JRE via the "build path" pages. However, an "installed JRE" only allows for one javadoc location (via the edit/add dialog for a JRE). Re-opening the "installed JRE" edit dialog will overwrite any individual jars that have been set by the user. About #35336:
It's not possible to set the javadoc location for a path that starts with a classpath variable. For instance <classpathentry kind="var" path="NEXT_SYSTEM_ROOT/Library/Frameworks/ JavaWebObjects.framework/Resources/Java/javawebobjects.jar"/>. NEXT_SYSTEM_ROOT is a valid classpath variable.
To make it a little bit clearer. It's possible to set the Javadoc location trough the UI interface. Anyway the info is not stored persistent. The information *is* persisted - it's just not persisted in the .project file. The information is persisted as a user setting, rather than a project setting. No it's not persistent. It's possible to set the javadoc location. After reopening the properites page the javadoc location is NONE. Yes - that's the bug. The info is persisted, but we incorrectly overwrite it. Nothing planned on debug side for 3.0. Moving to JUI for consideration (if JUI can selectively listen to VM changes/updates). I can reproduce the behavior of comment 0 in 3.0 RC1, with a pure SDK and a docs zip:
- expand the JRE System Library in the Package Explorer and select rt.jar, core.jar, or whatever the main jar in your installation is - context menu > Properties - set the Javadoc Location to "Javadoc in archive" and enter pathes for doc zip - click OK, open type Vector and press Shift+F2 => the javadoc is (correctly) taken from the jar for this session
- shut down eclipse, restart => the "Javadoc in archive" setting has been forgotten; all jars take the JRE's javadoc URL Created attachment 17614 Suggested fix
Problem description: The Javadoc locations are managed by jdt.ui. jdt.launching also keeps a javadoc location per vm install; jdt.launching does not know jdt.ui: jdt.ui therefore listens for vm changes and updates its locations whenever a location in a vm install changed.
jdt.launching can be loaded before jdt.ui and jdt.ui delays the loading of the javadoc locations to the first accessed of it. That means on initialization, the location store must assume that it might have missed some vm install changes since the last save.
The old code used to completly refresh all locations on initialize with the most actual vm install javadoc locations. Doing that it made unnecessary updates and always overwrote user changes.
The fix for 3.0.x is to always remember the last known vm install settings. On initalization, the remembered vm install settings are compared with the actual ones and only the locations for changed vm installs are updated.
The real fix will be to move the javadoc locations to jdt.core so jdt.launching can set them itself. reviewed by Dirk and Markus and released to 3.1 and 3.0.x stream > 20050209 Verified on M20050216-1722.

However, an "installed JRE" only allows for one javadoc location (via the edit/add dialog for a JRE). Re-opening the "installed JRE" edit dialog will overwrite any individual jars that have been set by the user. About #35336:
It's not possible to set the javadoc location for a path that starts with a classpath variable. For instance <classpathentry kind="var" path="NEXT_SYSTEM_ROOT/Library/Frameworks/ JavaWebObjects.framework/Resources/Java/javawebobjects.jar"/>. NEXT_SYSTEM_ROOT is a valid classpath variable.
To make it a little bit clearer. It's possible to set the Javadoc location trough the UI interface. Anyway the info is not stored persistent. The information *is* persisted - it's just not persisted in the .project file. The information is persisted as a user setting, rather than a project setting. No it's not persistent. It's possible to set the javadoc location. After reopening the properites page the javadoc location is NONE. Yes - that's the bug. The info is persisted, but we incorrectly overwrite it. Nothing planned on debug side for 3.0. Moving to JUI for consideration (if JUI can selectively listen to VM changes/updates). I can reproduce the behavior of comment 0 in 3.0 RC1, with a pure SDK and a docs zip:
- expand the JRE System Library in the Package Explorer and select rt.jar, core.jar, or whatever the main jar in your installation is - context menu > Properties - set the Javadoc Location to "Javadoc in archive" and enter pathes for doc zip - click OK, open type Vector and press Shift+F2 => the javadoc is (correctly) taken from the jar for this session
- shut down eclipse, restart => the "Javadoc in archive" setting has been forgotten; all jars take the JRE's javadoc URL Created attachment 17614 Suggested fix
Problem description: The Javadoc locations are managed by jdt.ui. jdt.launching also keeps a javadoc location per vm install; jdt.launching does not know jdt.ui: jdt.ui therefore listens for vm changes and updates its locations whenever a location in a vm install changed.
jdt.launching can be loaded before jdt.ui and jdt.ui delays the loading of the javadoc locations to the first accessed of it. That means on initialization, the location store must assume that it might have missed some vm install changes since the last save.
The old code used to completly refresh all locations on initialize with the most actual vm install javadoc locations. Doing that it made unnecessary updates and always overwrote user changes.
The fix for 3.0.x is to always remember the last known vm install settings. On initalization, the remembered vm install settings are compared with the actual ones and only the locations for changed vm installs are updated.
The real fix will be to move the javadoc locations to jdt.core so jdt.launching can set them itself. reviewed by Dirk and Markus and released to 3.1 and 3.0.x stream > 20050209 Verified on M20050216-1722.

Bug.Summery: Cannot define multiple projects under common parent folder

Lines.Line: P.S. You may also want to know that I currently have Eclipse 2.1, build
200303272130 installed on the same box, with identically named projects
(I'm trying to start the porting process, you see). Obviously, the two
Eclipse installations are in separate folders with separate .metadata
folders. It has always been my impression that Eclipse ignores the Windows
registry, but if that's wrong, perhaps Eclipse3 is picking up some of my
1) In the directory F:\Eclipse3, I run 'jar xvf
2) Double-click desktop icon (created earlier) which has target:
3) Start the 'New Project' wizard by right-clicking in the Resource
4) In the 'Plug-in Project Name' WizardPage, enter the project name
6) Browse to the folder 'F:\Eclipse3\skade\plugins', creating new
folders as necessary, to populate the 'Directory' field.
8) On the 'Plug-in Project Structure' page, accept the defaults and
9) On the 'Plug-in Code Generators' page, choose 'Create a Blnk
10) Navigate to F:\Eclipse3\skade\plugins in Windows Explorer, see
has been created, containing subfolders 'src' and 'bin' and the
12) Repeat Step (4), only this time enter the project name
overlap.' appears, and I can't continue in the 'New Project'

Bug.WithStack:
I defined a new plugin project 'pluginA' and on the 'Plug-in Project Name' wizard page, I specified a path of F:\eclipsedev\plugins for the project contents. The wizard automatically created a directory F:\eclipsedev\plugins\pluginA and its contents.
When I attempted to define a second plugin project, 'pluginB', I specified the same path on the 'Plug-in Project Name' wizard page: F:\eclipsedev\plugins. However, the wizard did not allow this, and displayed the message:
"F:/eclipsedev/plugins and F:/eclipsedev/plugins/pluginA overlap"
However, had the wizard allowed me to continue, pluginB would have been created in its own, distinct directory.
This behavior is a regression from version 2.1.0, build 200303272130.
I'm currently using version 3.0, build 200307181617. What type of project are you trying to create? I cannot reproduce this problem. Do you have any more steps that I can follow to make it happen? This is what I am doing...what am I doing wrong?
In the New Project Wizard, I changed the name of the project to be PluginA and I un-checked the "use default" check box and entered \eclipsedev\plugins in the text field. After pressing Finish the .project file for the PluginA project was created (in \eclipsedev\plugins\.project) and an extra directory PluginA was NOT created. (this is expected behaviour) Comments from originator: ------------------------
After receiving your response, I stepped through the process again, and I still see the problem. I'm using Eclipse 3.0, build 200307181617; maybe you're using a newer development build? Here are the exact steps --- in my original post, I had changed the directory/plugin names from what I was really using, but here I'll provide the exact names, in case that makes a difference:
1) In the directory F:\Eclipse3, I run 'jar xvf eclipse-SDL-3.0M2-win32.zip'. 2) Double-click desktop icon (created earlier) which has target:
F:\Eclipse3\eclipse\eclipse.exe -data F:\Eclipse3\eclipsedata
3) Start the 'New Project' wizard by right-clicking in the Resource Navigator view, and select 'Plug-in Development'/'Plug-in Project'. 4) In the 'Plug-in Project Name' WizardPage, enter the project name 'com.lawson.lef'. 5) Uncheck the 'Use default' checkbox. 6) Browse to the folder 'F:\Eclipse3\skade\plugins', creating new folders as necessary, to populate the 'Directory' field. 7) Click 'Next'. 8) On the 'Plug-in Project Structure' page, accept the defaults and click 'Next'. 9) On the 'Plug-in Code Generators' page, choose 'Create a Blnk Plug-in Project' and click 'Finish'. 10) Navigate to F:\Eclipse3\skade\plugins in Windows Explorer, see that the directory F:\Eclipse3\skade\plugins\com.lawson.lef has been created, containing subfolders 'src' and 'bin' and the project metadata files. 11) Repeat Step (3). 12) Repeat Step (4), only this time enter the project name 'com.lawson.lef.navigator'. 13) Repeat Steps (5) and (6). 14) The error message 'F:/Eclipse3/skade/plugins and F:/Eclipse3/skade/plugins/com.lawson.lef overlap.' appears, and I can't continue in the 'New Project' wizard.
--dave
P.S. You may also want to know that I currently have Eclipse 2.1, build 200303272130 installed on the same box, with identically named projects (I'm trying to start the porting process, you see). Obviously, the two Eclipse installations are in separate folders with separate .metadata folders. It has always been my impression that Eclipse ignores the Windows registry, but if that's wrong, perhaps Eclipse3 is picking up some of my existing Eclipse 2.1 configuration data.
P.P.S. For the hell of it, I also tried defining a project named 'projectA', and in that case too, a 'projectA' folder was created. We have been unable to reproduce this problem because the Plugin Project wizard acts different from the Java and Simple project wizards. The plugin project wizard is appending the name of the project to the location provided in the wizard page. (org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.CoreUtility.createProject). Thus, if you create a project called "A" with a location of "c:\temp\skade\plugins":
For a Simple or Java project, you get a project like this:
c:\temp\skade\plugins c:\temp\skade\plugins\.project c:\temp\skade\plugins\.classpath c:\temp\skade\plugins\src ... etc...
For a Plugin Project, with the exact same path provided on the wizard page, you get the following:
c:\temp\skade\plugins\A c:\temp\skade\plugins\A\.project c:\temp\skade\plugins\A\.classpath c:\temp\skade\plugins\A\src ... etc...
The Plugin wizard should not be appending the name to the project location *** Bug 56758 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 53365 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Note that the "if" statement is still needed (to determine if we are using the default location) since the wizard page never returns null for the location. DJ, +1 for RC3? I'd give a +2 if I could. :-) The fix for this one is trivial. Instead of (inexplicably) appending the project name to the chosen location, we don't. Created attachment 12286 Patch for pde core
Cherie, please review patch. Beautiful patch.
Please release and resolve. Marking as fixed. DJ can live in peace now. I only wish... :-) Verified on I20040617-0800. *** Bug 62047 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The problem is back on 3.0.2 release. Somebody reverted the solution?

Bug.Summery: Internet Connection Dialog Implementaion
Bug.WithStack:
I would like to see and implementation of the windows internet connection manager. i think it woul be a good feature instead of having to manually open the connection dialog & connection before performing some internet task. Seems pretty plaform specific. Can you point to the API from the Windows MSDN that allows you to open this dialog? I'm marking this WONTFIX for now. i agree it is platform specific, but every platform has some kind of internet connection application, and is activex not quite specific? sorry, i'm not trying to be difficult or anything. i should probably just try doing this myself, but have no experience with JNI. the sdk is here anyway:
http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en- us/rras/rras/remote_access_service_functions.asp
