Bug.Summery: Incorrect lineAppended notification from ConsoleLineNotifier
Bug.WithStack:
The ConsoleLineNotifier will incorrectly notify that a line has been appended when the line is incomplete yet the process has terminated.
Test case can be an external Ant build from bug 41156.
If a line does not yet have a demiliter BUT the console process has terminated, the notifier still processes that line. This seems incorrect in general.
We notify the line trackers of the incomplete line region. Then consoleChange notification arrives for the further changes to the console document including the rest of the line that was just incorrectly processed. I need to look closer - but I recall this was to notify of the last line in the console (in case of no line terminator). Yes this is what I remember that code for as well. Fixed. Removed fix for bug 31734. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The ConsoleLineNotifier will incorrectly notify that a line has been appended when the line is incomplete yet the process has terminated.
Test case can be an external Ant build from bug 41156.
If a line does not yet have a demiliter BUT the console process has terminated, the notifier still processes that line. This seems incorrect in general.
We notify the line trackers of the incomplete line region. Then consoleChange notification arrives for the further changes to the console document including the rest of the line that was just incorrectly processed. I need to look closer - but I recall this was to notify of the last line in the console (in case of no line terminator). Yes this is what I remember that code for as well. Fixed. Removed fix for bug 31734. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: [launching] Launch config templates

Lines.Line: - Describe the application to be launched
- Describe the input to that application
- Describe the environment in which it is to be launched

Bug.WithStack:
Currently it is possible to pass arguments to the JVM that Eclipse runs in with the -vmargs option on the command line. The options given, however, aren't used when running a unit test or application; these start in their own JVM. The JVM's arguments can be set from the "Run..." option.
It would be nice to have a way to configure a default set of arguments to the VM so that they don't have to be configured for every Run configuration individually. For example, it might be really nice to be able to pass something like this to every Run instance by default:
-DproxySet=true -DproxyHost=foobar -DproxyPort=1080
(rather than having to set those up individually for every Junit class, etc) Launching issue. Moving to JDT/Debug. *** Bug 43621 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Since different users seem to have different attributes they want to share/re- use between configs, I see this as a general request for launch config templates. Marking as deferred. Currently, we do not have the resources to implement such a feature in 3.0. *** Bug 46000 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 46435 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 47522 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 51999 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 52028 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 62590 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 72755 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 74092 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 77008 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I have some config files and other resources stored in a directory that I have to add to the class path for all executables in my project. So, in addition to default arguments, I would like to tack on default classpath additions. *** Bug 79453 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is one of those Idea features that I miss very much. *** Bug 110770 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Could this bug be considered for 3.2? It has quite a few duplicates and it would eliminate the need for various launch-kind-specific workarounds such as bug 45408 comment 4. Not planned for 3.2, not enough time/resources. There's another similar enhancement request: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=67585
Please vote for it as well. *** Bug 136355 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 137731 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 89670 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** reopening Note that you can workaround this by adding your specific VM arguments in the eclipse.ini file (as it is done for -Xmx and Xms) and append these VM arguments in your launch config while creating it (set the check-box "Append the VM arguments specified in the target's launcher INI file" in the "Launching Arguments" tab of the Plug-in Development -> Target Platform preference page).
This bug should really have a higher priority. Please consider for 3.5. *** Bug 234400 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 240373 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** My bug 89670 got marked as a dupe, but I'm not sure that this entirely captures my enhancement request.
I was asking that we break apart the options that: - Describe the application to be launched - Describe the input to that application - Describe the environment in which it is to be launched
...in which case the launch configuration itself would simplified to a choice of application, environment, and input. I'm not sure that providing a default set of VM arguments would entirely provide the functionality I'm looking for.
*** Bug 256005 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Please consider this for 3.5. Sorry, this is not on the 3.5 plan and it is too late for 3.5. Resources were never allocated to do the work. I believe this is a big enough work item/feature that it would have needed to be in the M5 "big" feature freeze. Another possible requirement is to be able to create templates at different scopes - similar to preferences. For example, at user, project, and enterprise levels.
Created attachment 149582 Core infrastructure
First implementation of headless infrastructure to support launch configuration templates, with tests. The wiki has been updated with a design doc/use cases:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/Debug/Plan/3.6/Launch_Templates Any chance we could see and review a quick outside-in description of the UI before this is implemented?
I'm still not sure this will address my use-cases for bug 89670, which asks that I be able to separate the settings that describe the program being launched, its environment, and its input... and then be allowed to mix-and-match programs, configurations, and environments.
It's good to see some momentum here, but I assume that by the time this is fully coded, it will be to late to comment on the workflows. My appologies. I see you referenced a wiki page that I somehow missed. Please disregard my request for more details. Created attachment 152103 patch.
Work in progress. Hoewver, we've hit a snag as documented in the WIKI and on the mailing list. Since configurations can use the absence of an attribute to indicate data/trigger behavior, using a simple approach of copying attrbites from the template to the configuration does not work as expected. Work on templates has been deferred. To properly implement/integrate this feature requires more UI work than originally understood. The stumbling block centers around the fact that the UI needs to be able to distinguish which launch attributes are included in the template and which are not (as well as being able to validate templates properly). Just leaving attributes blank is not sufficient to denote that an attribute is excluded, as empty attributes can actually be relevant in templates (to indicate default settings such as using a project default JRE). Thus, integrating this feature would require all launch tab contributors to contribute new UI for templates - our hope was to be able to re-use existing implementations with no/minimal changes from exiting implementations.
As well, being able to integrate templates with launch shortcuts/configuration creation (for example, default template for project), requires changes in existing implementations.
We simply don't have the resources available to implement this feature. I understand that a complete solution is expensive, but would a partial implementation be possible? By the sounds of the comments, what people need is the ability to provide global JVM args. In my case I want to be able to say that all Java processes should start up with -Xmx1024m. Could a field be made available on a project where I could specify that? It's not a complete solution, but might cover a large portion of the requests.
There would be the question of what to do if one of the JVM args is 'overridden' in a run target. I don't know how the JVM would respond to arguments like this: "-Xmx1024m -Xmx512m". I'd hope that it takes the last argument, but I haven't checked. (In reply to comment #39) > I understand that a complete solution is expensive, but would a partial > implementation be possible? By the sounds of the comments, what people need is > the ability to provide global JVM args. In my case I want to be able to say > that all Java processes should start up with -Xmx1024m.
Note that JREs already support VM arguments that get applied to all launches. You can add VM args to the JRE's "Default VM Arguments" text box available via: Preferences -> Java -> Installed JREs > Edit... We are having the same need for templates but for the list of active plug-ins rather than just VM arguments (which can be taken care of by modifying the "Target Platform" in the PDE Preferences). For development we have some plug-ins installed (e.g. subversion) which definitely we don't want active when running the unit tests, and automatically created run/debug configurations for junit or SWTBot include "all workspace and enabled target plugins" so we need to manually edit the configuration every time. >include "all workspace and >enabled target plugins" so we need to manually edit the configuration every >time. Why? Can't you simply disable the bundles in your Target Platform? *** Bug 339196 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Are there any plans to include this feature in one of the next eclipse releases?
Because there is no possibility to change the working directory of new launch configurations automatically. I need this because I want to separate the launch folder from my workspace when I launch a Java application. (In reply to Lars Briem from comment #44) > Are there any plans to include this feature in one of the next eclipse > releases? > > Because there is no possibility to change the working directory of new > launch configurations automatically. I need this because I want to separate > the launch folder from my workspace when I launch a Java application.
We are not working on this, but as indicated, help will be appreciated.

Work in progress. Hoewver, we've hit a snag as documented in the WIKI and on the mailing list. Since configurations can use the absence of an attribute to indicate data/trigger behavior, using a simple approach of copying attrbites from the template to the configuration does not work as expected. Work on templates has been deferred. To properly implement/integrate this feature requires more UI work than originally understood. The stumbling block centers around the fact that the UI needs to be able to distinguish which launch attributes are included in the template and which are not (as well as being able to validate templates properly). Just leaving attributes blank is not sufficient to denote that an attribute is excluded, as empty attributes can actually be relevant in templates (to indicate default settings such as using a project default JRE). Thus, integrating this feature would require all launch tab contributors to contribute new UI for templates - our hope was to be able to re-use existing implementations with no/minimal changes from exiting implementations.
As well, being able to integrate templates with launch shortcuts/configuration creation (for example, default template for project), requires changes in existing implementations.
We simply don't have the resources available to implement this feature. I understand that a complete solution is expensive, but would a partial implementation be possible? By the sounds of the comments, what people need is the ability to provide global JVM args. In my case I want to be able to say that all Java processes should start up with -Xmx1024m. Could a field be made available on a project where I could specify that? It's not a complete solution, but might cover a large portion of the requests.
There would be the question of what to do if one of the JVM args is 'overridden' in a run target. I don't know how the JVM would respond to arguments like this: "-Xmx1024m -Xmx512m". I'd hope that it takes the last argument, but I haven't checked. (In reply to comment #39) > I understand that a complete solution is expensive, but would a partial > implementation be possible? By the sounds of the comments, what people need is > the ability to provide global JVM args. In my case I want to be able to say > that all Java processes should start up with -Xmx1024m.
Note that JREs already support VM arguments that get applied to all launches. You can add VM args to the JRE's "Default VM Arguments" text box available via: Preferences -> Java -> Installed JREs > Edit... We are having the same need for templates but for the list of active plug-ins rather than just VM arguments (which can be taken care of by modifying the "Target Platform" in the PDE Preferences). For development we have some plug-ins installed (e.g. subversion) which definitely we don't want active when running the unit tests, and automatically created run/debug configurations for junit or SWTBot include "all workspace and enabled target plugins" so we need to manually edit the configuration every time. >include "all workspace and >enabled target plugins" so we need to manually edit the configuration every >time. Why? Can't you simply disable the bundles in your Target Platform? *** Bug 339196 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Are there any plans to include this feature in one of the next eclipse releases?
Because there is no possibility to change the working directory of new launch configurations automatically. I need this because I want to separate the launch folder from my workspace when I launch a Java application. (In reply to Lars Briem from comment #44) > Are there any plans to include this feature in one of the next eclipse > releases? > > Because there is no possibility to change the working directory of new > launch configurations automatically. I need this because I want to separate > the launch folder from my workspace when I launch a Java application.
We are not working on this, but as indicated, help will be appreciated.

Bug.Summery: Allow new template types to be defined by plugins
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 3.0 is planning to support non-Java partitions in the Java editors. Currently you can only define java or javadoc templates. I would like to be able to define a new template type different from java or javadoc which could be used in a new non-Java partition. For example, I would like to define a template of type SQLJ that would contain a template for a valid #sql clause. This is now possible with the org.eclipse.ui.editors.templates extension point. Any editor may choose to support a specific context type (which map to partitions in many ways), and can offer contributed templates, or even template resolvers if it chooses so.
The java editor currently does not support any other context types, but it does not support other languages either.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Eclipse 3.0 is planning to support non-Java partitions in the Java editors. Currently you can only define java or javadoc templates. I would like to be able to define a new template type different from java or javadoc which could be used in a new non-Java partition. Any editor may choose to support a specific context type (which map to partitions in many ways), and can offer contributed templates, or even template resolvers if it chooses so.
The java editor currently does not support any other context types, but it does not support other languages either.

Bug.Summery: Not all builders are executed when changing the javaBuildPath

Lines.Line: 1) document this behaviour for builder writters (who should look for a resource
2) run a full build in case of classpath change

Bug.WithStack:
when changing javaBuildPath properties in the project properties page, and closing the page, only the JavaBuilder gets executed. This could be a problem especially if there exists other builders which do bytecode manipulation, or depend on class file execution, since not running them leaves the project in an unstable state. Martin, can you please comment. What I do is a 'serRawClasspath', JCore does the rest. Moving to JCore for comments.
My guess is that other builders that depend on the classpath of a Java project should listen to Java element deltas (where classpath changes are reported), and not rely that a full build of a project is performed.
martin's guess is right, the JavaBuilder indeed checks for classpath change in the delta. The point is that changing the classpath causes an implicit full_build with javaBuilder being the only builder to run, which is inconsistent.
Either : 1) document this behaviour for builder writters (who should look for a resource change with path = projectroot + ".classpath", or 2) run a full build in case of classpath change
Setting a classpath doesn't trigger a build per se. It is only a side effect of JDTCore touching the .classpath file, creating thus a resource change which in turn causes builder(s) to run whenever platform decides (automatically or when user explicitly build).
Our Java builder then decides to perform a full build internally since it doesn't want to get into an incremental mode for such a change.
As long as subsequent builders are properly observing resource changes, then will correctly react to a classpath change. If they want to know how the classpath did change, then additional Java delta listeners should be used.
The .classpath file is an internal artifact and should remain as such.
If you are seeing a scenario where the platform doesn't correctly trigger all downstream builders when the Java builder is invoked, then you should reopen this defect and reassign it to Platform/Core. JDT/Core doesn't trigger any build action, it only reacts to a build request.
Bug.WithOutStack:
when changing javaBuildPath properties in the project properties page, and closing the page, only the JavaBuilder gets executed. My guess is that other builders that depend on the classpath of a Java project should listen to Java element deltas (where classpath changes are reported), and not rely that a full build of a project is performed.

Either : 1) document this behaviour for builder writters (who should look for a resource change with path = projectroot + ".classpath", or 2) run a full build in case of classpath change
Setting a classpath doesn't trigger a build per se. It is only a side effect of JDTCore touching the .classpath file, creating thus a resource change which in turn causes builder(s) to run whenever platform decides (automatically or when user explicitly build).
Our Java builder then decides to perform a full build internally since it doesn't want to get into an incremental mode for such a change.
As long as subsequent builders are properly observing resource changes, then will correctly react to a classpath change. If they want to know how the classpath did change, then additional Java delta listeners should be used.

If you are seeing a scenario where the platform doesn't correctly trigger all downstream builders when the Java builder is invoked, then you should reopen this defect and reassign it to Platform/Core. JDT/Core doesn't trigger any build action, it only reacts to a build request.

Bug.Summery: percflow aspects compiled from jars share one instance for all entry points
Bug.WithStack:
When a percflow aspect is woven into source code from a jar using the aspectPath compiler option, it produces only one instance of the aspect for each entrypoint defined in the source code. This bug needs a self-contained example in order to be verified and fixed. Here are two examples of bug reports for similar bugs that contained good examples:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=39462 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41123
It would be very valuable to us if you could provide a similar example for this bug. Thanks for your help.
Created attachment 5863 test project with build.xml
Here's a test case that demonstrates the bug. The default ant target tests the aspect code first compiled along with the test and then tests a second time with the aspect in a jar and the testcase compiled with the jar in the aspect path.
To use the build.xml in this project, you'll need to create a lib folder in the project containing aspectjrt.jar, aspecttools.jar, and junit.jar. Also, in order for the ant tasks to work, it will be a good idea to drop junit jar in ANT_HOME/lib
The results of both tests can be found in html form under ./dist/junit_output Created attachment 5898 decompiled normally compiled code
Shows attached (normally compiled) test code after being decompiled Created attachment 5899 decompiled jar compiled code
Shows attached (compiled from jar) test code after being decompiled This is a great test case and easy to reproduce. I've raised this to a P2 bug. The general problem is that any code that extends an abstract aspect from a .jar file does not inherit the per-clause from the super-aspect, so all such aspects behave like persingletons. This is true for percflow, pertarget and perthis.
The simple work-around is to explicitly include the per-clause in the concrete aspects declaration, i.e.: aspect MyTestPerCFlowEntryPoint extends PerCFlowCompileFromJar percflow(topOfFlow()) {
The bug is now fixed in the tree and should be in the 1.1.1 release.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When a percflow aspect is woven into source code from a jar using the aspectPath compiler option, it produces only one instance of the aspect for each entrypoint defined in the source code. https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=39462 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=41123
It would be very valuable to us if you could provide a similar example for this bug. Thanks for your help.

This is true for percflow, pertarget and perthis.
The simple work-around is to explicitly include the per-clause in the concrete aspects declaration, i.e.: aspect MyTestPerCFlowEntryPoint extends PerCFlowCompileFromJar percflow(topOfFlow()) {

Bug.Summery: Jface documentation improvement suggestion
Bug.WithStack: Hi, It seems that TableLabelProvider.getColumText() must return an empty string and not null to indicate no text in the cell. The documentation doesn't say, and it's not totally obvious - for instance a null image indicates no image. I wouldn't even mention it except the exception that's thrown isn't easily traceable to the root cause: org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.AssertionFailedException: assertion failed: The application has not been initialized. Which is pretty confusing. The javadoc for getColumnText states: * @return String or or null if there is no text for the * given object at columnIndex If returning null causes errors, please enter a bug report against the component that is not correctly handling null (which according to spec it must handle).
Bug.WithOutStack: Hi, It seems that TableLabelProvider.getColumText() must return an empty string and not null to indicate no text in the cell. The documentation doesn't say, and it's not totally obvious - for instance a null image indicates no image. I wouldn't even mention it except the exception that's thrown isn't easily traceable to the root cause: org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.AssertionFailedException: assertion failed: The application has not been initialized. Which is pretty confusing. The javadoc for getColumnText states: * @return String or or null if there is no text for the * given object at columnIndex If returning null causes errors, please enter a bug report against the component that is not correctly handling null (which according to spec it must handle).

Bug.Summery: GTK-BIDI: RTL support in TabFolder
Bug.WithStack:
Direction of packing of rtl-oriented TabFolder's tabs should be changed to opposite. Text direction of each tab's contents should be set separately. Created attachment 5698 Code, which should be added to os.c Created attachment 5699 OS.java from build N20030729 with proposed changes
Our changes are marked with tag "b41363". Created attachment 5700 TabFolder.java from build N20030729 with proposed changes
Our changes are marked with tag "b41363". See GTK-BUG http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=96630 We should contribute to GTK base code and have this problem fixed in GTK.
Created attachment 7830 TabFolder.java from build I20040210 with proposed changes.
Starting with GTK 2.3.3, GtkNotebook (and therefore TabFolder) supports RTL flipping. It is supposed here, that general problem, which is described in the bug 41184,
is solved by the newly suggested way. In addition we should set orientation of TabItem's tree of GTK widgets and permit focus traversing to GTK (in opposite case scrolling of the tabs can't work). Our changes are marked with tag b41363. fixed HEAD > 20050224

Bug.Summery: GTK-BIDI: RTL support in Combo

Lines.Line: 1. Initial position of horizontal scroll bar should be changed to rightmost
2. X position of window, which contains drop-down list, should
be changed to leftmost position of Combo.

Bug.WithStack:
All currently found problems in rtl-oriented Combo are connected with it's drop- down list. Text direction of each item of this list should be set separately. Position of vertical scroll bar of it's scrolled window should be changed to opposite. Initial position of horizontal scroll bar should be changed to rightmost position. X position of window, which contains drop-down list, should be changed to leftmost position of Combo. As far as I understand, last problem can't be solved with current version of GTK without handling of widget's visibility changing. GTK places list's window in accordance with leftmost position of entry widget, that isn't leftmost widget in case of rtl orientation of Combo. Created attachment 5702 Combo.java from build N20030729 with proposed changes
Our changes are marked with tag "bidi". They don't include changes,which are needed for setting horizontal scroll bar to rightmost position. Problem with position of horizontal scrollbar of list is currently discussed in the comments to bug 41243. Your code does not fixed two of the problems you mention:
1. Initial position of horizontal scroll bar should be changed to rightmost position. 2. X position of window, which contains drop-down list, should be changed to leftmost position of Combo.
I believe we can fix both problems, but it will be very hacky.
Created attachment 7831 Combo.java from build i20040210 with proposed changes.
Starting with GTK 2.3.2, the most problems of rtl-oriented Combo are solved. Some additional changes are needed here because of this control's specifics. It is supposed here, that general problem, which is described in the bug 41184,
is solved by the newly suggested way. Our changes are marked with tag b41364. fixed in head > 20050223 Created attachment 80315 Zip, wich contains doc with screenshots and some diff files. This bug should be reopened, because bidi-specific problems appear in Combo again. This is caused by change base GTK widget, used by Combo, from GtkCombo to GtkComboBox. I don't touch here general GTK problems with contextual ordering of the text and dynamic alignment in GTK text widgets. Problems, specific for SWT Combo, consist in wrong alignment of drop-down list's content and wrong alignment of the text, which appears in not-editable Combo's cell view (see attachments). Reason: correct text direction isn't set for corresponding GTK widgets. To change their direction, we need found and save handles of these widgets. Case of cell view from not-editable Combo is more simple: its handle can be found in the list of GtkComboBox children. What about drop-down list, it is released inside additional toplevel Window. Handle to this Window can be found by comparing lists of toplevels before and after creating GtkComboBox. Our suggestions can be found in attachments as diff files, which are done on the base of corresponding sources from 3.4M2.
Created attachment 80339 Last zip with doc and diff files Thank you for the patch! I released it to HEAD with some modifications. Should be in tomorrow's I-build - can you please give it a try at your end? Thanks!
Fixed in HEAD > 20071015 I checked with build I20071016 - it looks ok. Thank you.

Fixed in HEAD > 20071015 I checked with build I20071016 - it looks ok. Thank you.

Bug.Summery: Launcher loop behaviour after an un-install/re-install

Lines.Line: 2. Start the product to create a workspace
4. Re-install WSAD 5.1 to the same location
5. Try to start the product with the workspace from #2.
1. install a new feature to a different site (say, c:\newEclipse)
2. add a .link (in the links directory) to this new site
4. the above results in an infinite restarting loop
A fix for 2.1.2 is risky: we don't have a full understanding of the cause and
the code fixes would involve touching very sensitive code in the startup
The workarounds mentioned by Jeff should be fine. We will need to add them to
I have a similar problem, if u have a solution please let me know.
As of latest integration build, Eclipse startup should no longer have a 2-
phase startup that would trigger looping.

Bug.WithStack:
The is a problem found during the testing of WSAD 5.1
1. Install WSAD 5.1 (on Windows) 2. Start the product to create a workspace 3. Un-install WSAD 5.1 4. Re-install WSAD 5.1 to the same location 5. Try to start the product with the workspace from #2.
The product never comes up but repeatedly keeps showing the splash screen. The .log contains a bunch of lines like this:
java.fullversion=J2RE 1.3.1 IBM J9 build 20030702 (JIT enabled) BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_CA Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -data G:\workspaces\ws1 - install file:G:/installedWSAD/eclipse/ !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Problems encountered loading the plug-in registry. !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Two plug-ins found with the same id: "com.rational.clearcase.help". Ignoring duplicate at "file:g:/installedWSAD/rational/eclipse/plugins/com.rational.clearcase.help_2 .1.6/plugin.xml". !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Two plug-ins found with the same id: "com.rational.clearcase". Ignoring duplicate at "file:g:/installedWSAD/rational/eclipse/plugins/com.rational.clearcase_2.2.36 /plugin.xml". !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Two plug-ins found with the same id: "com.ibm.accessibility.doc". Ignoring duplicate at "file:g:/installedWSAD/wstools/eclipse/plugins/com.ibm.accessibility.doc_5.1. 0/plugin.xml". !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Two plug-ins found with the same id: "com.ibm.debug.help.doc". Ignoring duplicate at "file:g:/installedWSAD/wstools/eclipse/plugins/com.ibm.debug.help.doc_5.1.0/p lugin.xml". !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731 !MESSAGE Two plug-ins found with the same id: "com.ibm.debug.javascript.doc". Ignoring duplicate at "file:g:/installedWSAD/wstools/eclipse/plugins/com.ibm.debug.javascript.doc_5 .1.0/plugin.xml". !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.core.runtime 2 1 Jul 22, 2003 17:16:51.731
After an un-install, we completely removed the directory and the problem still happens, so this is not a case of some remnant from the first install remaining. This is a problem with the saved state in the workpace.
The workarounds we currently have are: 1) Install to a different location 2) Delete the workspace/.metadata/.config directory.
Marked this as major since it is quite ugly for our customers since one you get into the looping state, your only recourse is to kill the eclipse.exe and javaw.exe processes. This bug should be fixed once we move the config state out of the workspace. We have submitted a patch to the Core team and are waiting for its integration in a build. I managed to get a different scenario that also exhibits the launcher loop:
1. install a new feature to a different site (say, c:\newEclipse) 2. add a .link (in the links directory) to this new site 3. restart eclipse. 4. the above results in an infinite restarting loop A fix for 2.1.2 is risky: we don't have a full understanding of the cause and the code fixes would involve touching very sensitive code in the startup process. The workarounds mentioned by Jeff should be fine. We will need to add them to the README. I have a similar problem, if u have a solution please let me know. similar bug 44716. As of latest integration build, Eclipse startup should no longer have a 2- phase startup that would trigger looping.

Bug.Summery: CVS account gets locked: Multiple password enter requests

Stacktrace.Reason: : Authentication error: Invalid username, password, host or repository

Lines.Line: 1. Got new synch info via Live Synch view
==> multiple (> 3) password request dialogs were presented
- I did not receive a request that my password has expired
- I did not get any useful message why my password was rejected
I don't know what initially triggered the client to ask for the password. Can
you see this in some server log? I already asked help-infra to check their logs.

Bug.WithStack:
I20030806
After doing the following actions: 1. Got new synch info via Live Synch view 2. Pressed "Conflicts" button ==> multiple (> 3) password request dialogs were presented
If the CVS client automatcally retries to login instead of waiting for the first password query to be answered by the user the account probably gets disabled after the three automatic tries. This is bad since I can now no longer work until my account gets reset by the administrator. Even worse. If I startup Eclipse and it first tries the old invalid password more than once the opened account gets closed again.
Note: - I did not receive a request that my password has expired - I did not get any useful message why my password was rejected - nothing in .log I don't know what initially triggered the client to ask for the password. Can you see this in some server log? I already asked help-infra to check their logs.
I'm pretty sure that the multiple password word dialogs were caused by the experimental Quick Diff provider example (see bug 39812). Since this plug-in is only experimental the problem might go away when this feature is provided by the Team team. Is code in CVS core which prevents parallel logins while already one password request is underway? If this is not the case then this is a real problem especially with background jobs.
We found this last Friday as well. I will submit a fix for tomorrow integration build. This loophole has always existed, because we don't protected the login sequence for cancellation. With the new job support cancellation happens a lot more frequently.
To see the CVS logs, in the CVS preferences page there is a new option to turn on protocol logging and output to stdout.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 41161 *** I'm actually re-opening this one because although related to 41161 it highlights another point. Login prompting is not serialized. You won't really see this with the current Team core because we don't perform CVS operations concurrently.
This is one of the problems with the sample quick diff provider - it access team code that is not thread safe!
For the next integration build I have fixed a major problem with quick cancellation requests which also locked you out of an account. In my case the account first worked i.e. password was correct and account not locked: I got synch info and a file was compared with the server) and then I got about 5(!) password entry dialogs (which I think resulted in the locked account). So the main question is why was a wrong password sent to the server and/or the account locked after working a minute before?
I then got a new password form the webmaster, disabled CVS quick diff prototype, CVS decorators, and all CVS background stuff, went to the CVS Repository view and expanded HEAD. The password dialog came up (OK), I entered the new password and in the server log we saw several invalid attempts being tried and the account got locked again. Only after the webmaster unlocked and I tried again with the password that was now stored in the keyring I was able to connect again.
Kim Moir was watching the server log.
I think this is a critical bug since I was not able to work with the server for a whole day. This is a blocker. No idea why it thinks the account has to been locked. This morning I was catching up and again out of nowhere was presented with the password dialog though the password obviously was not wrong: when Kim unlocked the account I could work again even without entering any password.
My first guess was that there's a limit on connections per account (since I was also performing CVS operations in parallel on the build machine) but according to Kim there are no such restrictions.
Here's the log created by CVS when the connection failed - not sure whether this helps.

We haven't touch any code in this area for a long while. It is strange that it's suddenly happening so frequently now even with the background jobs. I will go talk to Kim and see if she has changed some configuration parameters on the server.
The other possible problem could be with some of the core changes and how they may affect the key ring file. Obviously if the password is never wrong then you should never be locked out in the first place. Is it possible that accessing CVS from two different accounts at the same time (maybe even same resources) might confuse the client e.g. because some message or warning is sent by the server?
I have experienced the pain of this problem yesterday very similar to Dani's experience. I was in the process of comparing changes and committing and then the account was locked. The scenario Darin explains was also the one that locked my account the first time: I was synchronizing with remote in the background (new live synch view) and during this process I compared a local file with its CVS content. Background fetching and operation preferences were disabled (work in progress page).
I upgraded openssh on dev to 3.5p1-6.9 on August 5. This upgrade addressed a security issue where pam modules were ignored in certain cases.
From Redhat's security page...
https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2003-222.html
When configured to allow password-based or challenge-response authentication, sshd (the OpenSSH server) uses PAM (Pluggable Authentication Modules) to verify the user's password. Under certain conditions, OpenSSH versions prior to 3.6.1p1 reject an invalid authentication attempt without first attempting authentication using PAM.
However, I inadvertently had an extra line in my in /etc/pam.d/system-auth. The line
auth required /lib/security/pam_tally.so deny=5 reset no_magic_root
where there should have only be a line like this....
account required /lib/security/pam_tally.so deny=5 reset no_magic_root
This module locks accounts if they exceed five password failures so it may have been the source of the problem. Once I fixed this, the problem went away. However, there still seems to be issues with the new rpm because an indication of authentication failure is written to /var/log/messages when the user authenticates via ssh both successfully and unsuccessfully.
This is reflected in bug
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=102174 Thanks Kim.
Can both Darin and Daniel confirm that you aren't experiencing this problem anymore? Can we close this? Doesn't this only explain why the account got locked? Why was a wrong password sent to the server? I would expect the CVS client to work even if a user account gets locked after 1 wrong try (of course its then the users fault if he enters a wrong password). I understood from Kim that correct passwords were actually being sent however the retry count was being incremented anyway.
As a result of this and another similar bug, we have fixed two areas of the CVS plugin that could result in incorrect passwords being sent:
1. It used to be possible to interrupt an SSH login sequence. This has been fixed and login sequences are protected against cancellation.
2. We have serialized login to the same repo. This will handle the cases where multiple threads try and login with incorrect passwords, thus possibly locking out the user. OK. I enabled CVS decorators and background fetching in the Synch view and did not experience a password related problem so far. I am experiencing the same problems as mentioned above. When I try to synchronize with a remote CVS server (running CVSNT), sometimes the sync proceeds correctly. At other times the "authentication failed" popup dialog would appear and prompt me for a password. I am very sure I have entered the CVS password correctly, although the password prompt keeps re-appearing. After a few tries my account gets locked on the CVS server, and I can't proceed to work until an administrator unlocks my account. Here are the relevant information:
Client machine: Windows XP CVS server: Windows 2000 Eclipse version: 3.0.1 Build id: 200409161125
I would appreciate it if anyone can offer any suggestions/work-arounds. I am re-opening this bug because, well, obviously, it's not working on my machine. Please let me know if you need any additional information from me to try to solve this.
Thanks! Irene Kam Could be related to bug 66885. Please add yourself to the CC of bug 66885 instead of reopening this one. Thanks.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20030806
After doing the following actions: 1. Got new synch info via Live Synch view 2. Pressed "Conflicts" button ==> multiple (> 3) password request dialogs were presented
If the CVS client automatcally retries to login instead of waiting for the first password query to be answered by the user the account probably gets disabled after the three automatic tries. This is bad since I can now no longer work until my account gets reset by the administrator. Even worse. If I startup Eclipse and it first tries the old invalid password more than once the opened account gets closed again.
Note: - I did not receive a request that my password has expired - I did not get any useful message why my password was rejected - nothing in .log I don't know what initially triggered the client to ask for the password. Can you see this in some server log? I already asked help-infra to check their logs.
I'm pretty sure that the multiple password word dialogs were caused by the experimental Quick Diff provider example (see bug 39812). Since this plug-in is only experimental the problem might go away when this feature is provided by the Team team. Is code in CVS core which prevents parallel logins while already one password request is underway? If this is not the case then this is a real problem especially with background jobs.
We found this last Friday as well. I will submit a fix for tomorrow integration build. This loophole has always existed, because we don't protected the login sequence for cancellation. With the new job support cancellation happens a lot more frequently.
To see the CVS logs, in the CVS preferences page there is a new option to turn on protocol logging and output to stdout.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 41161 *** I'm actually re-opening this one because although related to 41161 it highlights another point. Login prompting is not serialized. You won't really see this with the current Team core because we don't perform CVS operations concurrently.
This is one of the problems with the sample quick diff provider - it access team code that is not thread safe!
For the next integration build I have fixed a major problem with quick cancellation requests which also locked you out of an account. In my case the account first worked i.e. password was correct and account not locked: I got synch info and a file was compared with the server) and then I got about 5(!) password entry dialogs (which I think resulted in the locked account). So the main question is why was a wrong password sent to the server and/or the account locked after working a minute before?
I then got a new password form the webmaster, disabled CVS quick diff prototype, CVS decorators, and all CVS background stuff, went to the CVS Repository view and expanded HEAD. The password dialog came up (OK), I entered the new password and in the server log we saw several invalid attempts being tried and the account got locked again. Only after the webmaster unlocked and I tried again with the password that was now stored in the keyring I was able to connect again.
Kim Moir was watching the server log.
I think this is a critical bug since I was not able to work with the server for a whole day. This is a blocker. No idea why it thinks the account has to been locked. This morning I was catching up and again out of nowhere was presented with the password dialog though the password obviously was not wrong: when Kim unlocked the account I could work again even without entering any password.
My first guess was that there's a limit on connections per account (since I was also performing CVS operations in parallel on the build machine) but according to Kim there are no such restrictions.
Here's the log created by CVS when the connection failed - not sure whether this helps.
!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.ui 4 0 Aug 12, 2003 12:49:51.218 !MESSAGE Cannot connect to host !STACK 1 !ENTRY org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 4 Aug 12, 2003 12:49:51.218 !MESSAGE Cannot connect to host !ENTRY org.eclipse.team.ui 4 0 Aug 12, 2003 12:59:33.31 !MESSAGE Authentication error: Invalid username, password, host or repository !STACK 1
We haven't touch any code in this area for a long while. It is strange that it's suddenly happening so frequently now even with the background jobs. I will go talk to Kim and see if she has changed some configuration parameters on the server.
The other possible problem could be with some of the core changes and how they may affect the key ring file. Obviously if the password is never wrong then you should never be locked out in the first place. Is it possible that accessing CVS from two different accounts at the same time (maybe even same resources) might confuse the client e.g. because some message or warning is sent by the server?
I have experienced the pain of this problem yesterday very similar to Dani's experience. I was in the process of comparing changes and committing and then the account was locked. The scenario Darin explains was also the one that locked my account the first time: I was synchronizing with remote in the background (new live synch view) and during this process I compared a local file with its CVS content. Background fetching and operation preferences were disabled (work in progress page).
I upgraded openssh on dev to 3.5p1-6.9 on August 5. This upgrade addressed a security issue where pam modules were ignored in certain cases.
From Redhat's security page...
https://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2003-222.html
When configured to allow password-based or challenge-response authentication, sshd (the OpenSSH server) uses PAM (Pluggable Authentication Modules) to verify the user's password. Under certain conditions, OpenSSH versions prior to 3.6.1p1 reject an invalid authentication attempt without first attempting authentication using PAM.
However, I inadvertently had an extra line in my in /etc/pam.d/system-auth. The line
auth required /lib/security/pam_tally.so deny=5 reset no_magic_root
where there should have only be a line like this....
account required /lib/security/pam_tally.so deny=5 reset no_magic_root
This module locks accounts if they exceed five password failures so it may have been the source of the problem. Once I fixed this, the problem went away. However, there still seems to be issues with the new rpm because an indication of authentication failure is written to /var/log/messages when the user authenticates via ssh both successfully and unsuccessfully.
This is reflected in bug
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=102174 Thanks Kim.
Can both Darin and Daniel confirm that you aren't experiencing this problem anymore? Can we close this? Doesn't this only explain why the account got locked? Why was a wrong password sent to the server? I would expect the CVS client to work even if a user account gets locked after 1 wrong try (of course its then the users fault if he enters a wrong password). I understood from Kim that correct passwords were actually being sent however the retry count was being incremented anyway.
As a result of this and another similar bug, we have fixed two areas of the CVS plugin that could result in incorrect passwords being sent:
1. It used to be possible to interrupt an SSH login sequence. This has been fixed and login sequences are protected against cancellation.
2. We have serialized login to the same repo. This will handle the cases where multiple threads try and login with incorrect passwords, thus possibly locking out the user. OK. I enabled CVS decorators and background fetching in the Synch view and did not experience a password related problem so far. I am experiencing the same problems as mentioned above. When I try to synchronize with a remote CVS server (running CVSNT), sometimes the sync proceeds correctly. At other times the "authentication failed" popup dialog would appear and prompt me for a password. I am very sure I have entered the CVS password correctly, although the password prompt keeps re-appearing. After a few tries my account gets locked on the CVS server, and I can't proceed to work until an administrator unlocks my account. Here are the relevant information:
Client machine: Windows XP CVS server: Windows 2000 Eclipse version: 3.0.1 Build id: 200409161125
I would appreciate it if anyone can offer any suggestions/work-arounds. I am re-opening this bug because, well, obviously, it's not working on my machine. Please let me know if you need any additional information from me to try to solve this.
Thanks! Irene Kam Could be related to bug 66885. Please add yourself to the CC of bug 66885 instead of reopening this one. Thanks.

Bug.Summery: Paste to 'Choose a Resource' field of 'Open Resource' dialogbox does not work
Bug.WithStack:
Pasting a name of an existing resource to the 'Choose a Resource' field of the 'Open Resource' dialogbox does not result in displaying any matches in 'Matching Resources' field.
This does work in version Eclipse 2.1.0.
Workaround: typing instead of pasting the resource name. Note: pasting a name does work with the 'Open Type' dialogbox.
In 'Open Resource' dialogbox, type in '*.sql'. Result: no matching resources. Then delete the 'l' in '*.sql'. Result: all the matching '*.sql' resources are shown.
Should be fixed by Bug 41368 but we should verify. Verified fixed in build >20030811 Marking closed

Bug.Summery: [Threads and Monitors] How to see deadlocks in System threads?
Bug.WithStack:
I don't seem to be able to suspend system threads with the threads and monitors view so that i can detect deadlocks in system threads.
I really want that because currently RMI threads are System threads and i have a lot of RMI threads running and they are deadlocking somehow. But i can't see this with the current threads and monitors.
So i there should be an options that i can also say: use system threads. Or that i can seelect the threads and sya detect/use these threads. Luc, can you provide any instructions/details on this? We filter out the system thread from the thread & monitor view because we thought they were irrelevent for the user. Usually, the system threads don't execute user code.
There no way in the current implementation to display the system thread in the thread & monitor view. We should be able to add an option to display them if needed (or just remove the filter).
Darin W: do we want to add a preference in the view ? May be something like the 'show constants, show static, ...' in the variable view. I would just remove the filter (i.e. do not filter any threads). It avoids having to (yet) add another option :-) Fixed. I removed the filter.
Changes in MonitorManager and MonitorQuitAction. Please verify, Darin W. Verified

We filter out the system thread from the thread & monitor view because we thought they were irrelevent for the user. Usually, the system threads don't execute user code.

Darin W: do we want to add a preference in the view ? May be something like the 'show constants, show static, ...' in the variable view. I would just remove the filter (i.e. do not filter any threads). It avoids having to (yet) add another option :-) Fixed. I removed the filter.
Changes in MonitorManager and MonitorQuitAction. Please verify, Darin W. Verified

Bug.Summery: SourceField.getConstant() returns null for final fields set in initializer

source_code.code: /** * Returns the constant value associated with this field * or null if this field has none. * Returns either a subclass of Number, or a String, * depending on the type of the field. * For example, if the field is of type short, this returns * a Short. * * @return the constant value associated with this field or null if this field has none. * @exception JavaModelException if this element does not exist or if an * exception occurs while accessing its corresponding resource */

Lines.Line: 1) in the doc, the getConstant() method should specify that a constant is
returned only if the field is static and final or if the field is the field of
2) The implementation should convert the char[] to either an instance of a
subclass of Number or a String.

Bug.WithStack: For public class TestA { private final int fFoo= 3; } given fFoo as an IField, IField.getConstant() returns null. How is this supposed to work? It works only if the type is an interface, but it reports a char[] in case the field is from source. This is clearly a bug according to the doc. I think we have two bugs. One in the doc and one in the implementation. 1) in the doc, the getConstant() method should specify that a constant is returned only if the field is static and final or if the field is the field of an interface type. 2) The implementation should convert the char[] to either an instance of a subclass of Number or a String. In your example, null is the proper answer, because this field is not a constant field in the JLS meaning. Only static final fields can have a constant. If you change it to: public class TestA { private static final int fFoo= 3; } You will get the char array char[] {'3'} for the return value of getConstant() and this doesn't match the javadoc. /** * Returns the constant value associated with this field * or null if this field has none. * Returns either a subclass of Number, or a String, * depending on the type of the field. * For example, if the field is of type short, this returns * a Short. * * @return the constant value associated with this field or null if this field has none. * @exception JavaModelException if this element does not exist or if an * exception occurs while accessing its corresponding resource */ public Object getConstant() throws JavaModelException; That's fair. Is there another way aside from getConstant() to see what the value of a field is set to? For the source action "Generate constructor using fields..." I want to include final fields in the list of possible fields to choose to be initialized in an auto-generated constructor, but only if this field hasn't already been initialized. Moreover the constant could be converted to a Boolean instance or a Character instance and these are not either a subclass of Number or a String. So the javadoc should definitely be fixed. We might want to say that the constant is converted to the proper wrapper type. To answer your question, I don't think it is possible to do it using the IField. If you use the DOM/AST API, it is easy to find out if a field has an initializer. Fixed and released in HEAD. In your example, you won't get a constant, but for static final fields or interface's fields you will get the right constant and not a char[] anymore. Verified. Backported to 2.1.3. Verified for 2.1.3 with build M200402251535.
Bug.WithOutStack: For public class TestA { private final int fFoo= 3; } given fFoo as an IField, IField.getConstant() returns null. How is this supposed to work? It works only if the type is an interface, but it reports a char[] in case the field is from source. This is clearly a bug according to the doc. I think we have two bugs. One in the doc and one in the implementation. 1) in the doc, the getConstant() method should specify that a constant is returned only if the field is static and final or if the field is the field of an interface type. 2) The implementation should convert the char[] to either an instance of a subclass of Number or a String. In your example, null is the proper answer, because this field is not a constant field in the JLS meaning. Only static final fields can have a constant. If you change it to: public class TestA { private static final int fFoo= 3; } You will get the char array char[] {'3'} for the return value of getConstant() and this doesn't match the javadoc. /** * Returns the constant value associated with this field * or null if this field has none. * Returns either a subclass of Number, or a String, * depending on the type of the field. * For example, if the field is of type short, this returns * a Short. * * @return the constant value associated with this field or null if this field has none. * @exception JavaModelException if this element does not exist or if an * exception occurs while accessing its corresponding resource */ public Object getConstant() throws JavaModelException; That's fair. Is there another way aside from getConstant() to see what the value of a field is set to? For the source action "Generate constructor using fields..." I want to include final fields in the list of possible fields to choose to be initialized in an auto-generated constructor, but only if this field hasn't already been initialized. Moreover the constant could be converted to a Boolean instance or a Character instance and these are not either a subclass of Number or a String. So the javadoc should definitely be fixed. We might want to say that the constant is converted to the proper wrapper type. To answer your question, I don't think it is possible to do it using the IField. If you use the DOM/AST API, it is easy to find out if a field has an initializer. Fixed and released in HEAD. In your example, you won't get a constant, but for static final fields or interface's fields you will get the right constant and not a char[] anymore. Verified. Backported to 2.1.3. Verified for 2.1.3 with build M200402251535.

Bug.Summery: FormLayout.layout takes too long for more controls
Bug.WithStack:
Overview : I have added about 400 controls to a composite. When the layout set is FormLayout, the computation of position of controls takes really long time, and never seems to end.
Reproduction steps: Add about 250 or more controls to a single parent composite. Assign FormData, and try to .layout. As the algorithm starts computing positions, and the child index goes up, the perchild position computing time goes up exponentially.
Version : Found it in 2.1.1 and 2.0.2 This has already been fixed. Please get the latest SWT from CVS and try it out. If the problem is still there, then reopen this bugzilla report with some sample code that shows the problem. Thanks.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Overview : I have added about 400 controls to a composite. When the layout set is FormLayout, the computation of position of controls takes really long time, and never seems to end.
Reproduction steps: Add about 250 or more controls to a single parent composite. Assign FormData, and try to .layout. As the algorithm starts computing positions, and the child index goes up, the perchild position computing time goes up exponentially.
Version : Found it in 2.1.1 and 2.0.2 This has already been fixed. Please get the latest SWT from CVS and try it out. If the problem is still there, then reopen this bugzilla report with some sample code that shows the problem. Thanks.

screenshot
This will also cause problems for translations like French, since you will also have to match the gender (un/une).. and there is no way to determine what gender the type will be. Best to avoid using the word "a" altogether if possible.

Bug.Summery: [Progress] NPE in progres view while cancelling a job
Appending call to plugin.startup to static Initializer will not work

Lines.Line: - there is no way (that we know of) to catch class init events. The closest we
can get is classload. Classes are loaded for many reason (e.g., verification of
other classes). We are really only interested in activation when code is
actually being run, not just loaded.
- The net result of this is eager activation and too much code loaded. It is a
sort of self-perpetuating model. The more you load the more you activate. The
more you activate, the more you load...
- There are some subtle concurrency issues since classloaders are at least
partially synchronized. We may have worked through most of these but then again

Bug.WithStack:
Jeff McAffer/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA 08/04/2003 11:25 PM To Keith Kimball/Westford/IBM@IRIS@IBMUS cc Pascal_Rapicault@ca.ibm.com Subject Re: Skeptical that we can safely patch existing static initializers
Its interesting because technically speaking, some flavour of this is true today in Eclipse. Say plugin P.startup() looks like... P.startup() { Foo.initialize(); Bar.start(); ... } The static clinit() and initialize() or start() for Foo and Bar (respecitively) cannot rely on P being fully activated since they are used in the process of activating P, perhaps unknown to them. In particular, Foo.initialize() will not be able to take advantage of whatever Bar.start() does.
The case you point out is more subtle. Basically, once someone has attempted the first clinit(), that class will not be fully initialized for the remainder of the activation. In the current Eclipse the trigger is classload and infact the class that triggered the startup can be loaded/run as part of the startup sequence. We simply check after doing the activation to see if the class we were about to load was loaded for us. Since people can try to load a class many times this works. In your case the system makes it impossible to call clinit() more than once.
All I can think right now is "Damn! There must be a way!"
As for using the classloader, this is what we do currently. It is "ok" but has some bad characteristics - there is no way (that we know of) to catch class init events. The closest we can get is classload. Classes are loaded for many reason (e.g., verification of other classes). We are really only interested in activation when code is actually being run, not just loaded. - The net result of this is eager activation and too much code loaded. It is a sort of self-perpetuating model. The more you load the more you activate. The more you activate, the more you load... - There are some subtle concurrency issues since classloaders are at least partially synchronized. We may have worked through most of these but then again maybe not.
Please continue to think about it and see what you can come up with. Pascal, can you chat with Chris and perhaps a VM guy (e.g., GAC) to see what you can see.
Jeff
Keith Kimball@IRIS 08/04/2003 08:46 PM
To: Pascal_Rapicault@ca.ibm.com@IBMCA cc: Jeff McAffer/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA Subject: Skeptical that we can safely patch existing static initializers
Pascal,
I want to thank you again for giving me a hard deadline. It is so much easier to say "no" to other requests when your deadline is approaching.
I may not understand what you're asking for, but I fear that in general it is not safe to patch an existing static initalizer to call "new Plugin().startup()". Assume you prepend the startup call, the startup call will fail if it references a variable which is initialized later in static initializer. Consider the following:
> cat FirstLoad.java import java.util.Hashtable; import Plugin;
public class FirstLoad { static public Hashtable hashTable = null;
static public void insertedCode() { Plugin plugin = new Plugin(); plugin.startup(); }
static { insertedCode(); // references hashTable hashTable = new Hashtable(); } }
> cat Plugin.java import FirstLoad;
public class Plugin { public void startup() { FirstLoad.hashTable.put("foo","bar"); System.out.println(">> Plugin Started"); } }
The inverse also holds, if you append instead of prepend the startup call, have the static initializer reference a variable initialized by the startup call.
Instead of patching the initializer, would it possible to modify the ClassLoader to realizer it is loading the 1st class from a plugin and do the startup call prior to loading the class?
Keith Auto-activation has is being done explicitly in the Eclipse adaptor classloaders. When we detect that we've failed to find the desired class anywhere else (import and required bundles) and are about to look in self, we optimistically auto-activate (if required) expecting that we will find the desired class. There is the slim chance that we will not and thus will have activated eagerly but this is rare. It should only happen in cases where someone is really looking up a bogus class or where there is package splitting.
Closing *** Bug 41492 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Note, incorrect duplicate. Ignore comment 2
Bug.WithOutStack:
Jeff McAffer/Ottawa/IBM@IBMCA 08/04/2003 11:25 PM To Keith Kimball/Westford/IBM@IRIS@IBMUS cc Pascal_Rapicault@ca.ibm.com Subject Re: Skeptical that we can safely patch existing static initializers
Its interesting because technically speaking, some flavour of this is true today in Eclipse. Say plugin P.startup() looks like... P.startup() { Foo.initialize(); Bar.start(); ... } The static clinit() and initialize() or start() for Foo and Bar (respecitively) cannot rely on P being fully activated since they are used in the process of activating P, perhaps unknown to them. In particular, Foo.initialize() will not be able to take advantage of whatever Bar.start() does.
The case you point out is more subtle. Basically, once someone has attempted the first clinit(), that class will not be fully initialized for the remainder of the activation. In the current Eclipse the trigger is classload and infact the class that triggered the startup can be loaded/run as part of the startup sequence. We simply check after doing the activation to see if the class we were about to load was loaded for us. Since people can try to load a class many times this works. In your case the system makes it impossible to call clinit() more than once.
All I can think right now is "Damn! There must be a way!"
As for using the classloader, this is what we do currently. It is "ok" but has some bad characteristics - there is no way (that we know of) to catch class init events. The closest we can get is classload. Classes are loaded for many reason (e.g., verification of other classes). We are really only interested in activation when code is actually being run, not just loaded. - The net result of this is eager activation and too much code loaded. It is a sort of self-perpetuating model. The more you load the more you activate. The more you activate, the more you load... - There are some subtle concurrency issues since classloaders are at least partially synchronized. We may have worked through most of these but then again maybe not.
Please continue to think about it and see what you can come up with. Pascal, can you chat with Chris and perhaps a VM guy (e.g., GAC) to see what you can see.
Jeff

Bug.Summery: Unable to restore editor when restoring session on Solaris
Bug.WithStack:
I had a CDT session with various source-file windows open, in both C/C++ Perspective and Debug perspective. I then chose to upgrade CDT (to 1.2.0.21) using the Update Manager.
Upon restarting after the Update ... A pop-up dialog complained: unable to open editor for "App2.cpp". Other editors opened fine (although perhaps only H files and Makefiles).
At the same, this message occurred three times on console: Unable to restore editor - createElement returned null for input element factory: org.eclipse.ui.part.FileEditorInputFactory
The following message was found (3x) in the .metadata/.log file: !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 Aug 07, 2003 09:24:13.805 !MESSAGE Unable to restore editor - createElement returned null for input element factory: org.eclipse.ui.part.FileEditorInputFactory PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 I guess the problem is outdated.

Bug.Summery: Linker errors in Tasks view unhelpful
Bug.WithStack:
Using the latest and greatest of the most supported tool-chain (gcc-3.3, binutils 2.12, make 3.80) and I only get the following 2 tasks: [X] *** [Application2] Error 1 [X] ld fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 The second error (from the linker) has Location of "line 0". We do not know what symbol is undefined, or where they were used.
I must resort to the log file for details: Undefined first referenced symbol in file App2::sayHello() App2.o ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 collect2: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [Application2] Error 1
At a minimum, I would expect to be able to figure out from the Tasks view which symbols are undefined. (Where they are first referenced is less useful.)
Otherwise, we are providing a poor example of how other tool-chains should be supported within CDT. PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 Recent binutils don't use this format for unresolved symbols. The new format gets picked up correctly. We will not support this older format out of the box. > The new format gets picked up correctly.
I'll take your word for it.

Using the latest and greatest of the most supported tool-chain (gcc-3.3, binutils 2.12, make 3.80) and I only get the following 2 tasks: [X] *** [Application2] Error 1 [X] ld fatal: Symbol referencing errors. Bug.Summery: In C-Build log, tabs should be 8 chars wide
Bug.WithStack:
The (gcc) linker output expects a console (such as C-Build) to have 8-char tabs:
Undefined[\t][\t][\t]first referenced symbol[\t][\t][\t] in file App2::sayHello() App2.o ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 collect2: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [Application2] Error 1
The first two lines contain tabs, which are treated as 4 chars wide. This means that the third line does not properly align with the column headers. (It is possible to change the C/C++ Editor tab size from Preferences, but not the Build Console's tab size; that's fine, but its tab size should be 8.) PR was targeted at 2.0 but was not resolved at release time. Changing target to 2.1 build console has configurable tab size
Bug.WithOutStack:
The (gcc) linker output expects a console (such as C-Build) to have 8-char tabs:
Undefined[\t][\t][\t]first referenced symbol[\t][\t][\t] in file App2::sayHello() App2.o ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 collect2: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [Application2] Error 1
The first two lines contain tabs, which are treated as 4 chars wide. This means that the third line does not properly align with the column headers. (It is possible to change the C/C++ Editor tab size from Preferences, but not the Build Console's tab size; that's fine, but its tab size should be 8.) PR was targeted at 2.0 but was not resolved at release time. Changing target to 2.1 build console has configurable tab size

Bug.Summery: Build errors are sorted such that Make errors come first
Bug.WithStack:
Build errors are sorted on the Tasks view such that Make errors come first, whereas on a console they would come last.
Take for example the following build log: [X] *** [Application2] Error 1 [X] ld fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2
The error from Make should come last (certainly last among the errors, if not after the warnings). I think errors are sorted by line number, but Make provides no line information of course (and the linker error is assigned to line 0).
Also note the unnecessary extra space before the ***. (perhaps the reason for the sort?) The text in the CBuild log is as follows: ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 collect2: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [Application2] Error 1 PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 The make errors now only appear if there are no other errors.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build errors are sorted on the Tasks view such that Make errors come first, whereas on a console they would come last.
Take for example the following build log: [X] *** [Application2] Error 1 [X] ld fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2
The error from Make should come last (certainly last among the errors, if not after the warnings). I think errors are sorted by line number, but Make provides no line information of course (and the linker error is assigned to line 0).
Also note the unnecessary extra space before the ***. (perhaps the reason for the sort?) The text in the CBuild log is as follows: ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to Application2 collect2: ld returned 1 exit status make: *** [Application2] Error 1 PR was targeted to the 2.0 release but not resolved, moving target to 2.1 The make errors now only appear if there are no other errors.

Bug.Summery: ensure that declaration info shows correctly in outline view
Bug.WithStack:
AJDT has been ported to the new ASM API. There were some problems with the info showing up on the old API, and some of the logic for determining it has changed.
The following properties should be visible as overlays on nodes: - runnables - implementors - modifiers - visibility
Also ensure that imports show up identically to the JDT. runnables/modifiers and visibility are all fixed.
What did you mean by implementors? Mik, this is pretty old, and I'm not aware of any current problems here, so I'm marking it as fixed. Please reopen if I've missed anything.
By "implementors" I meant the little blue triangle that you see when a method implements an abstract method in a superclass. I think that it's green in the case of overrides, and blue in the case of imlements. I know that the other overlays work, but am not sure if this one does. Could you check?
As indicated in comment #3, overriders and implementors still don't work. *** Bug 78606 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The standard outline page now works fine, and I'm going to consider the old custom outline page to be deprecated and not fix problems with it.
