Bug.Summery: [java debug] UI frozen while debugged process is doing a stack overflow - no way to suspend

source_code.code: //1FTUHE0: ITPCORE:ALL - API - Status & logging - loss of semantic info),

Bug.WithStack:
Create a simple java application with the following main class :
public class StackOverflow {
public static void main(String[] args) { new StackOverflow().stackOverflow(); }
public void stackOverflow() { stackOverflow(); } }
Start the debugger. The UI is immediately frozen, the launched process is growing slowly, and eating all the CPU of the processor it is running on, but you have no way to suspend the main thread and see where it is. After a while you get some updates on the debug view, but you still can't act, all threads are shown as "not responding".
Note : this is not a CPU usage issue (SMP workstation). It just seems that there is no temporary polling of the jdwp socket while doing such kind of loops within the JRE...
Platform : Eclipse 2.1.1 JRE : Sun 1.4.2 OS : XP After searching a bit while I had a similar bug, it seems that the followings things are needed: -Xint so that the jre gets some control over the executed code. This is required if we don't want the debugger to be stalled. -Additional logging org.eclipse.ui.internal.ExceptionHandler.log( Throwable ) when adding a breakpoint to this method, and evaluating t.printStackTrace(), we get the proper information (provided -Xint was set and so the ui was not stalled by a pending debugger request)
in WorkbenchPlugin.log( String message, IStatus status ) (where there is the comment: //1FTUHE0: ITPCORE:ALL - API - Status & logging - loss of semantic info), there is the following stuff :
- getDefault().getLog().log(StatusUtil.newStatus(IStatus.ERROR, message, null)); Puts a message in the log
- System.err.println(message + "\nReason:"); //$NON-NLS-1$ Displays a "Reason:" string to stderr
- getDefault().getLog().log(status); Puts the stack trace in the log
- System.err.println(status.getMessage()); Puts a simple message
This is a bit painful, because then the console displays :
Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.stackOverflowError
whereas the stack trace was available and displaying it whould be really more efficient for developpers than having to look in the log file...
Note that the messagebox shown after is not useful without Policy.DEBUG_OPEN_ERROR_DIALOG set...
So far many issues, I think they should be documented. I'll write an article for eclipse.org site ;-)
I believe that the UI is unresponsive since we are attempting to update the view in the UI thread (once you suspend the thread). This may be helped once we have bug 16036 fixed. I think that issue is not solved with the (fixed) bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=16036 and I think there is a very pragmatic solution: Add a configuration option at "Windows > Preferences > Debug": "Max StackFrames in Debug View" [ 100 ] And If you are kind you may add a Debug-view context menu point: "Extended Stacktrace". I think the stack layout should look like:
topframe topframe-1 topframe-2 topframe-3 .... omitted 10000 frames ... base frame+6 base frame+5 base frame+4 base frame+3 base frame+2 base frame+1 base frame+0 I think nobody is intressten in the ommited 10000 frames and if so it he has to change the option or use the context menu.
Note I had (moderate) success debugging a stack overflow by setting an exception breakpoint for the StackOverflowException and also setting the the java thread stack size to 1000 using -Xss1000. UI remained fairly responsive but I agree we should investigate possible improvements. I know this trick, but I had no success with -Xss1M (=?= -X1000), on my Athlon 1400 MHz, I used (=?= -X300k) and had a very long delay until something happend. This trick is not very scalable because if I set it to -X100k I got a fast response -- because the Sun JVM bootclassloader had an stackoverflow error. You agree you should investigate possible improvements: that sounds as you don't like my suggested improvement. So I do some advertising (mle for president ;-) - my solution is: [*] More then a dirty fix, because it makes the stack trace more readable [*] Is a real extension of the current debug view (if the the context menu is extended), i.e. there is no functionallity lost. [*] It should become very simple to implement. [*] In remote debugging situation a very small stackdepth may become configurated to improve debugger performance (due to reduced debugger network traffic) But I really have no idea how fine grained the JVM debugger API is: I asssume it is possible to request the stackdepth of a suspended thread and each stackframe individual (or better intervalls of it). If that is not true then everything is lost ... . Deferred *** Bug 102646 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is mostly fixes now with async viewers. The remaining issue is the same as in bug 128255 (Java evaluation context manager updating in UI thread).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 128255 ***

Create a simple java application with the following main class :

public static void main(String[] args) { new StackOverflow().stackOverflow(); }
public void stackOverflow() { stackOverflow(); } }
Start the debugger. After a while you get some updates on the debug view, but you still can't act, all threads are shown as "not responding".
Note : this is not a CPU usage issue (SMP workstation). It just seems that there is no temporary polling of the jdwp socket while doing such kind of loops within the JRE...

This is required if we don't want the debugger to be stalled. -Additional logging org.eclipse.ui.internal.ExceptionHandler.log( Throwable ) when adding a breakpoint to this method, and evaluating t.printStackTrace(), we get the proper information (provided -Xint was set and so the ui was not stalled by a pending debugger request)
in WorkbenchPlugin.log( String message, IStatus status ) (where there is the comment: //1FTUHE0: ITPCORE:ALL - API - Status & logging - loss of semantic info), there is the following stuff :
- getDefault().getLog().log(StatusUtil.newStatus(IStatus.ERROR, message, null)); Puts a message in the log
- System.err.println(message + "\nReason:"); //$NON-NLS-1$ Displays a "Reason:" string to stderr
- getDefault().getLog().log(status); Puts the stack trace in the log
- System.err.println(status.getMessage()); Puts a simple message
This is a bit painful, because then the console displays :
Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: java.lang.stackOverflowError
whereas the stack trace was available and displaying it whould be really more efficient for developpers than having to look in the log file...
Note that the messagebox shown after is not useful without Policy.DEBUG_OPEN_ERROR_DIALOG set...
So far many issues, I think they should be documented. I'll write an article for eclipse.org site ;-)
I believe that the UI is unresponsive since we are attempting to update the view in the UI thread (once you suspend the thread). This may be helped once we have bug 16036 fixed. I think that issue is not solved with the (fixed) bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=16036 and I think there is a very pragmatic solution: Add a configuration option at "Windows > Preferences > Debug": "Max StackFrames in Debug View" [ 100 ] And If you are kind you may add a Debug-view context menu point: "Extended Stacktrace". I think the stack layout should look like:
topframe topframe-1 topframe-2 topframe-3 .... omitted 10000 frames ... base frame+6 base frame+5 base frame+4 base frame+3 base frame+2 base frame+1 base frame+0 I think nobody is intressten in the ommited 10000 frames and if so it he has to change the option or use the context menu.
Note I had (moderate) success debugging a stack overflow by setting an exception breakpoint for the StackOverflowException and also setting the the java thread stack size to 1000 using -Xss1000. UI remained fairly responsive but I agree we should investigate possible improvements. I know this trick, but I had no success with -Xss1M (=?= -X1000), on my Athlon 1400 MHz, I used (=?= -X300k) and had a very long delay until something happend. This trick is not very scalable because if I set it to -X100k I got a fast response -- because the Sun JVM bootclassloader had an stackoverflow error. You agree you should investigate possible improvements: that sounds as you don't like my suggested improvement. So I do some advertising (mle for president ;-) - my solution is: [*] More then a dirty fix, because it makes the stack trace more readable [*] Is a real extension of the current debug view (if the the context menu is extended), i.e. there is no functionallity lost. [*] It should become very simple to implement. [*] In remote debugging situation a very small stackdepth may become configurated to improve debugger performance (due to reduced debugger network traffic) But I really have no idea how fine grained the JVM debugger API is: I asssume it is possible to request the stackdepth of a suspended thread and each stackframe individual (or better intervalls of it). If that is not true then everything is lost ... . Deferred *** Bug 102646 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is mostly fixes now with async viewers. The remaining issue is the same as in bug 128255 (Java evaluation context manager updating in UI thread).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 128255 ***

Bug.Summery: Adoptability: CDT lacks ability to specify the "default" build target.

Lines.Line: - Preferences > Workbench > Perform build automatically on resource mod = YES.

Bug.WithStack:
For large projects, a developer is rarely going to "make all" from the root of their project. That will typically perform a large load-build. Load-builders are not our primary target users.
The average developer in a large project is much more likely to perform a "make all" in a subdir, or even a "make stub" in a subdir. It is possible to setup these targets from the Make Targets view. However to build them, the user must keep using the right-click action "Build" on that target in that view. This is not nearly as convenient (and the view wastes precious screen space) as any of: - Project > Build project - Ctrl-B - Preferences > Workbench > Perform build automatically on resource mod = YES. which perform "make -k".
The mechanism to specify "Build" is probably most possible within Make Targets view. I suggest a default target "" added to the Make Targets view's root dir, and decorate it as the default target. Then add a right-click action to make a different target the default. Then the user can hide the Make Targets view and perform builds conveniently as above.
Similarly, the Make Targets view could come pre-populated with "all" and "clean all" targets which could be similarly decorated and redefinable to fit the user's needs. Then a lot of the hidden voodoo magic becomes a little less hidden and a little more helpful. This is being address in the "new" Make builder, good feedback.
Dave, what do you think ? New builder addresses immediated problem of not being able to change default build targets, the rest could be handled as a feature request. Verified on build 1.2.0.60: The default build target is now user-specifiable, and clearly controllable.
Added bug43915 "Ctrl-B does not always build project" to track separately.
Added enhancement bug43917 "Synchronizing Make Build properties and Make Targets view"

Bug.Summery: switch -o appears twice in auto generated makefile

the switch -o appears twice in the auto-generated makefile and so building of a CPP-Program isn't possible I've debugged CDT and found that in MakefileGenerator.java

Bug.Summery: shortcut for New Folder
Bug.WithStack:
Currently in the Java Perspective if you right click on a folder in the Navigator you get the option of creating a New Project, Class, Interface, Package or Other. In order to create a new folder you have to go to Other, Simple, Folder.
Since I'm using the Navigator and not the Packages Viewer I would expect the folder creation to be trivial like it is in the Resources Perspective. I have the following menu entries under New when selecting a folder in the Navigator:
Project Package Class Interface Source Folder Scrapbook Page Folder <<< File Example Other
Am I missing something ? I'm using 2.1.1 and that happens in the Java Browsing perspective not Java perspective as I've mentioned above (sorry). OK, the problem is that the workbench only supports customizing the New menu per perspective. Since the Projects view doesn't show folders we decided to not add it to the New menu. Otherwise user will create folders, but they don't show up in the view.
As long as the workbench doesn't provide better support for the new menu there is nothing we can do.
Moving to platform for comments. There are currently no plans to work on this feature

Bug.Summery: [prototype] stopping bundle 0 should shutdown the framework
Bug.WithStack:
We need framework shutdown by stopping the system bundle implemented (please see OSGi spec section 4.2.1).
Today, it stops bundle 0 and lives the framework in an inconsistent state (e.g. status does not work afterwards). This is fixed in the new implementation.
Bug.WithOutStack:
We need framework shutdown by stopping the system bundle implemented (please see OSGi spec section 4.2.1).
Today, it stops bundle 0 and lives the framework in an inconsistent state (e.g. status does not work afterwards). This is fixed in the new implementation.
